<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
I love GMX. It has a great infrastructure, as it is located in Germany, which means it does not go through US and other NSA-related spy gates. It has a solid email and calendar, good search, solid spam filter (it is easy to see what the system considers spam, and it has an easy way to whitelist anything you consider not spam), and it offers great integration to a whole range of social and business services. But best of all, the service is free!
You’ve said in the past that you are working on a way to create your own email service. What is your primary focus: making sure it works as well as GMX does, or will you differentiate it in other ways?
I have been working on several initiatives over the last few years. Some were successful and some not. The lesson learned is that unless you’re Microsoft, Google, or Apple, it’s extremely hard to succeed as a newcomer in the Internet world. However, the lesson learned also was that people are desperate for an alternative, so if you manage to get something out there, you are going to be successful. And of course the success can be leveraged further if you get the right people on board.
When people use services they don’t have full control over, the fear of losing access to data and contact information is real. That’s a problem I want to address. Also, I want to offer services that are so good that no one would want to use anything else but our services.
What do you see as the main barrier to innovation in the email space?
The barrier to innovation in email has been there for a while. And the reason for that is the dominance of Gmail, Yahoo, and Hotmail. That is true for email and also for many other applications such as social networking, mapping, and search. But the dominance of the big players is also the reason why innovation in these areas is possible. These companies make so much money that it is hard to find other ways to make money. The other way, as I mentioned before, is to get the right people on board who are really passionate about an idea or a product. I believe this is what is happening now in email.
In this day and age, we’re all on various social networks. Do you think email has a future?
Yes. There are so many things you can’t do with Facebook or Twitter. But I think email is more of a long-term business, so it’s more stable and trustworthy than the social networks that we can use at any moment.
Finally, which apps and services do you use the most these days?
Mostly my own apps, like Muzzle, a mobile app that blocks spam and social ads. I don’t use any Google services for email or anything else. I don’t really like Google much, especially since they decided to force you to use Gmail if you use other services of theirs.</s>

With email, you can exchange your ideas directly and unbureaucratically with your customers, business partners or employees. In this article, you can find out about the different advantages of email, what providers are on the market and what is worth considering when making your decision.
Advantages of email
The advantages of email are obvious, because emailing is a very efficient communication channel. Companies can use it to provide their customers with up-to-date information or to keep them up to date with new offers. Employees can communicate easily and quickly internally. And all this is independent of the Internet connection – if you don’t have an email address, you can’t exchange emails. In short, email is a powerful tool for digital communication that can be used anywhere, anytime, and which provides many advantages.
Disadvantages of email
The advantages of email are obvious, but there are also some disadvantages to be aware of. One is that it takes time to manage all incoming emails. Apart from that, many emails are not protected by encryption and therefore provide access to unauthorized third parties. As a result, email is not always the best way to communicate sensitive or confidential information.
Email providers and their functions
The most important email providers in the German-speaking world are the following:
Yahoo! Mail: the largest free email service provider, offers various functions, such as an address book and spell checker.
Gmail: free email service of Google, offers many functions, such as spam filtering and virus protection.
Hotmail: the email service of Microsoft, offers various functions, such as spam filtering and virus protection.
Mailbox.org: this email provider, based in Germany, is completely free and offers various functions, such as spam filtering and virus protection.
Zoho Mail: email service with a focus on security and privacy. It offers an encrypted mailbox and secure attachments.
Mailchimp: not an email provider per se, but one of the leading email marketing services on the market. It offers various features such as templates and autoresponders.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
You’ve already given me an answer: SparkPost. There are a few other solid players out there, but the SparkPost platform is the best combination of reliability and innovation that we have seen.
A good example is our recent introduction of the SparkPost Webinar Integration. We are always looking for ways to make the email sending process easier and more streamlined for marketers, and this has been a real win for our customers.
When it comes to the GDPR, what advice do you have for marketers?
If you think of the GDPR as a framework, there are several things you can do to put yourself on the right path. These include:
Making sure your company has an email policy in place, along with a way for recipients to opt-out
Making sure that every email that is sent is compliant with the GDPR
Establishing clear and well-defined procedures to be followed when it comes to emails, including when to send marketing emails, how to manage opt-outs and when to delete subscriber data
Ensuring you have the technology in place to make all of this happen smoothly
This is, of course, a good start. To take it to the next level, however, you need to start preparing for the ePrivacy Regulation, which will follow the GDPR. It will require some even more significant changes, especially for those companies that are relying on cookies and other tracking technologies. This will take more time and effort, and it needs to start now.
Aside from the GDPR, which other email marketing challenges do you foresee this year?
As I mentioned earlier, in my view, the GDPR is the most important email marketing challenge that is currently looming, and I believe that it is something that every email marketer needs to be aware of. It affects both marketers and recipients, and I see a real threat to the email marketing industry as a whole.
The ePrivacy Regulation will also be a significant issue for many businesses. It has been drafted in a way that would have significant effects on email marketing, and while this is not something I see as a huge challenge, there will likely be a need for new technology that would enable companies to address this issue effectively.
What are some of the best email campaigns you’ve seen lately?
A great email campaign has several characteristics that, when combined, make it stand out from the crowd. These include:
It uses a highly targeted segmentation of recipients to increase the open and click-through rates.
It uses a single subject line that is easy to understand and can be used across multiple platforms.
It includes an effective call to action that tells the recipient exactly what to do next.
It includes a clear and well-designed unsubscribe form.
There are many more aspects to a successful email campaign, and the best way to ensure that you are getting the results that you want is to work with a company that has a lot of experience with this.
If you want to improve your email marketing efforts, take a look at the SparkPost Webinar Integration, which makes it easy to send high-quality emails that will drive engagement.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
We chose Gmail, and it has been a successful choice. In my opinion, Google has a very good service that is constantly developing.
There is always something new to experiment with, and Gmail has many additional services that are useful.
And we’ve found that Google G Suite integrates well with our internal systems and offers good value for money.
How has your company been using the Google G Suite?
We’re still discovering and learning how to get the most out of it. But for me, I love it!
We started using it because of the collaboration tools, but what we discovered is that there is a great number of small things in Gmail that make it easy to find what you need.
So, in short, I use it a lot!
And I think that’s how I have learned the most about its strengths and how I can make the most of them.
One of my favourite functions is undoubtedly the integration of Google Docs.
It has been a game-changer.
Google offers good support for integrating Docs into your daily work, as well as other services like Google Keep.
How do you manage your mailboxes?
Our employees usually keep 10 to 15 inboxes at once, which is a lot.
We’ve tried a few different ways of managing this, and we’ve come to the conclusion that one of the best is to create labels for our different types of communication.
We’ve got labels like sales, marketing, support, and general, which are all organized into folders.
When we need to search for an email from our support, we can quickly find it.
That way, we’ve also managed to reduce the number of inboxes we have to keep.
The inboxes are not cluttered with unread emails anymore.
We only have the ones we need.
It’s a great improvement!
How do you integrate email with your other communication methods?
We use Skype for team communication and it’s a great tool for online meetings and project coordination.
For project management, we’re trying to integrate Trello into Gmail, but we haven’t figured it out yet.
Gmail offers some good features for sharing information and managing project coordination, so that’s something we’re thinking about.
How has your company managed the transition to cloud computing?
The transition was very easy.
We started moving our infrastructure to the cloud when we realized we needed more flexibility and capacity than we had in-house.
We started with cloud services like Office 365 and then expanded to G Suite, which has been a big step forward.
We’ve found that the integration of G Suite has been really good.
The transition was seamless, and we’ve found it very easy to manage and maintain.
It’s also been great for collaboration.
We can work together and have all the information and tools we need to collaborate efficiently.
The company is also looking to use other cloud services like Microsoft Teams and Skype for Business.
But right now, it’s not that important for us because we’re focused on using G Suite to its full potential.
We can’t wait to discover all the new features that Google is working on!
What do you think of the Gmail user experience and how it integrates with the company’s other services?
I think Gmail is a great service that offers a lot of great features.
The user experience is really good and it’s easy to navigate.
We love it because it is very user-friendly.
And it’s always being improved and updated, which is great.
We also love the integration with other Google services, like Calendar and Google Keep.
These services are very useful and easy to use, and they’re a great way to stay organized and on top of your work.
Gmail has been a big step forward for us and our employees, and we hope to continue using it for many years to come.

I would say that the two main things that make an email provider the most secure are encryption and two-factor authentication (2FA).
Encryption is the process of converting data into a code that only the recipient can decrypt. This makes it much more difficult for hackers to access your data, as they would need the decryption key to do so.
Two-factor authentication (2FA) is an extra security measure that requires you to provide a second form of identification in addition to your password, such as your phone number or email address. This makes it much more difficult for hackers to gain access to your account, as they would need both your password and another form of identification.
While there are many email providers that claim to be secure, I would say that the two main things that make an email provider the most secure are encryption and two-factor authentication (2FA).
In my opinion, there are three major security problems that email providers need to address in order to ensure that their users’ email accounts are secure.
First, email providers need to do a better job of encrypting their users’ email traffic. This includes both the email messages themselves and any attachments that are sent along with them. Encrypting email traffic is the best way to ensure that hackers cannot intercept and read the contents of your emails.
Second, email providers need to be more vigilant about detecting and blocking spam emails. Spam emails are a major security problem for email users, as they can contain malicious attachments or links that can harm your computer or personal information.
Third, email providers need to be more transparent about their security practices. When it comes to email security, there are a few key features that every provider should offer. These include:
Spam filtering: Spam filtering is essential in order to keep your inbox free from unwanted emails.
Two-factor authentication: Two-factor authentication adds an extra layer of security to your account by requiring a second form of identification, such as your phone number or email address.
Encryption: Encryption is a process that scrambles your data so that it can only be read by the intended recipient. This makes your emails more secure and difficult to intercept.
VPN: A VPN (virtual private network) encrypts your internet traffic and protects your data from being intercepted by third parties.
Email archiving: Email archiving helps to keep your emails organized and easy to access, even if you delete them from your inbox.
Password protection: Password protection helps to keep your account secure by requiring you to enter a password before you can access your account.
Data encryption: Data encryption scrambles your data so that it can only be read by the intended recipient. This makes your data more secure and difficult to intercept.
Cloud storage: Cloud storage provides you with a secure way to store your data online. This is especially useful for businesses that need to share large files with their employees or customers.
User authentication: User authentication helps to keep your account secure by requiring you to enter a username and password before you can access your account.

Olivier: I think that for most people, the best email service provider remains Gmail. This is a great choice because it allows users to send and receive emails, to manage their inbox, and to access different features and tools, like Google Calendar, Google Docs, and Google Hangouts.
It also offers a number of useful features for users to filter incoming email and to manage their inbox. These include labels and categories, which allow users to organize their emails according to different categories, such as “Personal” or “Work.” Gmail also offers advanced search options that allow users to quickly find specific emails.
In terms of security, Gmail has strong security measures in place to protect user data. This includes two-factor authentication, which requires users to verify their identity using a secondary device, such as a mobile phone, when logging in to their account.
Overall, Gmail is a reliable and secure option for managing your email, and it provides a range of useful features and tools that make it an attractive option for businesses and individuals.
In your opinion, is it still essential to use email providers like Gmail, or can an alternative be used to get the same job done?
Olivier: In my opinion, it is still essential to use email providers like Gmail in order to stay connected with friends, family, and colleagues. Gmail is a reliable and convenient way to send and receive messages, and it offers a range of useful features, such as labeling and filtering, which can help to manage your inbox more effectively.
However, it’s important to be aware of the security and privacy risks associated with using email providers. For example, Gmail may scan your emails for advertising purposes, and this can lead to unwanted ads appearing in your inbox.
Additionally, if you are concerned about your privacy, you may want to consider using a more secure email provider that offers end-to-end encryption, such as ProtonMail or Tutanota. These providers use advanced security measures to protect your data, such as zero-knowledge encryption, which ensures that your messages are encrypted before they are sent.
Overall, while it’s still essential to use email providers like Gmail for communication and collaboration, it’s important to be aware of the security and privacy risks that come with using these services and to take steps to protect your data.
Can I use Gmail for my small business needs?
Olivier: Gmail can be a good option for small businesses in some situations. It provides a range of features, such as labeling and filtering, that can help to manage your inbox more effectively. It also offers a number of useful tools, such as Google Calendar and Google Docs, which can be useful for collaboration and task management.
However, it’s important to consider the limitations of Gmail for small businesses. For example, Gmail’s storage limits can be a problem for small businesses that send and receive a large volume of emails. Additionally, Gmail is not designed for the management of business data, and it may not be suitable for storing sensitive business information.
To ensure that your small business runs smoothly and effectively, it’s important to consider alternative email providers that offer more robust features and capabilities, such as Google Workspace or Microsoft Office 365. These providers offer more storage space, advanced security measures, and the ability to manage business data, making them a better choice for small businesses.
Should I move away from using email to get work done?
Olivier: While email can be a useful tool for communication and collaboration, it’s important to consider alternative methods for getting work done. Email is not always the best tool for managing tasks and projects, as it can be time-consuming and difficult to track progress. Additionally, email can be a security risk, as messages are stored in the cloud and can be accessed by anyone with access to your account.
Instead, consider using project management software, such as Asana or Trello, to manage your projects and tasks. These tools offer a range of features, such as task lists, task boards, and automated reminders, that can help you to stay organized and on track.
You can also use collaboration tools, such as Google Docs or Microsoft Word, to share and collaborate on documents. These tools allow multiple users to work on a document at the same time, and they provide tools for tracking changes and providing feedback.
Overall, while email can be a useful tool for communication and collaboration, it’s important to consider alternative methods for getting work done. This will help you to be more productive and efficient, and will help to ensure that your projects and tasks are managed effectively.

As of 2020, email is still the most popular and important form of communication on the internet, used by millions of people every day. Many of these users have accounts on different providers, so it can be difficult to determine which one is the best. However, there are a few email providers that stand out for their superior inbox organization and features.
Google’s Gmail platform has been around since 2004 and is one of the most widely used email providers today. The platform is known for its ease of use and reliability, as well as its intuitive interface and useful features such as spam filtering and archiving. It also offers features like labels and filters that can help organize your inbox and make it easier to find important messages.
Another popular email provider is Microsoft’s Outlook.com, which was launched in 2013 and offers similar features to Gmail such as spam filtering, archiving, and labels. However, Outlook.com also includes features like contact management and task lists that can help organize your inbox even further.
Yahoo Mail is another widely used email provider, though it is not as widely used as Gmail or Outlook.com. Yahoo Mail offers features such as a built-in calendar and contact management tools that can help organize your inbox as well as features such as spam filtering and archiving.
Other email providers that stand out for their organization include Apple’s Mail app, which comes pre-installed on all Apple devices; Zoho Mail, which offers an intuitive user interface and advanced filtering options; and ProtonMail, which provides an end-to-end encrypted email service that is perfect for those who value privacy.
Overall, Gmail, Outlook.com, Yahoo Mail, Apple’s Mail app, Zoho Mail, and ProtonMail are some of the email providers that stand out for their superior organization and features.

By emailing questions like this to our email experts, you can stay informed and ahead of the game in this constantly evolving field. We spoke with some of the top experts in the industry and asked them to recommend a suitable email provider for your needs. They’re experts, so you can trust their recommendations!
Jerry Low, founder of Web Profits and an email marketing expert
Ray Sidney-Smith, digital marketer and founder of MailPoet
Chris Goward, CEO of WiderFunnel, email optimization company
Bryan Harris, founder of Videofruit, email marketing expert
Jerry Low is a self-confessed geek who founded web profit to help other people make money from their websites, like his own online marketplace called SaleHoo.
He’s been in the game since 2004 and has run email campaigns to increase website conversions since 2006. The reason: a love for helping people succeed.
“My business is all about helping entrepreneurs to grow their business online, and for the last 10 years I’ve used email to increase conversions. I use email for:
Converting more people from search to my website
Getting people to sign up to my newsletter (my sales funnel)
Getting people to purchase from my site
Getting people to buy a membership from my site
The best email marketing software I use for email is MailChimp. I also use MailChimp for our business email accounts and newsletter for our business. The service is reliable and there are lots of features available that help businesses to convert more sales. The other reason I like MailChimp is that the free account lets you email 2000 people per month. Many other email marketing software doesn’t offer that kind of flexibility, and when you are just starting out, that can be crucial,” says Jerry.
Ray Sidney-Smith is a full-stack developer with 15 years of experience, with a background in ecommerce, WordPress and open-source. He’s the founder of MailPoet, a WordPress plugin for email marketing.
Ray recommends MailPoet for WordPress.
“MailPoet is a complete email marketing system for WordPress that is highly flexible for both beginners and experts. It’s packed with all the features you need to start marketing with email, including:
Full-featured sign-up forms, for both self-hosted WordPress sites or hosted sites like Wix and Weebly.
Automation for welcome emails, new subscriber emails, and autoresponders for other campaigns.
A fully-fledged campaign builder, so you can create and send an email in a matter of seconds.
Real-time reporting on opens, clicks, bounces, spam, and more.
You can easily create and schedule posts to your blog from inside your MailPoet account, and there’s a built-in calendar to keep you organised. And with one click, you can sync your campaigns with Google Analytics and Google Tag Manager to understand how your email campaigns affect your site visitors and customers.
MailPoet is also open-source, so if you ever need something that’s not covered by the plugins’ features, you can make changes directly to the source code. With so many options for customising MailPoet, you can start with a free account and scale up to meet your business needs.
Chris Goward is the founder and CEO of WiderFunnel, a behavioral marketing optimization company.
“We don’t recommend any one specific email marketing provider. But we are big believers in the following:
The customer has to be at the center of everything you do, and that includes your email strategy. To build a relationship with your customer that goes beyond marketing, you have to be a little bit more like them and speak to their goals, not yours.
The more you understand how your customer thinks and behaves, the more you can create the kind of value they want to hear from you.
Email is the #1 most powerful way to engage with your customers.
Email is 40x more effective than Facebook and Twitter combined, and 6x more effective than a tweet or Facebook post. Email is also the top channel for customer engagement, and the preferred method of customer service communication.
The email address is the key identifier for your customers, making it critical to use the right email marketing system that gives you the tools to understand your customer, and to deliver the right message at the right time.
With the right technology, you can improve email marketing efficiency by 25-50%.
There are 1.7 billion email users worldwide and more than 269 billion emails sent every day.
With so many emails being sent, email deliverability is more critical than ever. Email marketing is a volume game, so the more email you can send, the more likely you will be able to engage with your customer and influence their behavior. To do this, you need a solid email deliverability system, to ensure that you can email the right person at the right time.
Email is a powerful channel for engagement and conversion. The problem is that most businesses are failing to use it effectively. And if your email marketing is not working for you, it is time to ask yourself the tough questions about why. Is your email list out of date? Is your email marketing system delivering the right message to the right person at the right time? And do you have the right analytics in place to measure your performance?” says Chris.
Bryan Harris is a serial entrepreneur, email marketing expert, and the founder of Videofruit.
“I’m all about simplicity, so I use MailChimp for email marketing. MailChimp is super easy to use and their customer support is always on point!
I used to pay $25/month for the MailChimp Essentials plan, but after moving my business to SendPulse, I can get all the same features for $2/month (that’s 10X the savings!). SendPulse is a no-brainer,” says Bryan.

Some of the most popular email marketing providers include MailChimp, Constant Contact, and Infusionsoft. All of these providers offer a wide range of features and tools that can help you grow your business. However, each provider has its own strengths and weaknesses.
MailChimp is one of the most popular email marketing providers on the market. It offers a wide range of features and tools, including automation, A/B testing, customer segmentation, and more. It’s a great choice for businesses that are just starting out in email marketing or for those who want to experiment with different features and tools.
However, MailChimp can be a bit overwhelming for new users. It has a steep learning curve, and some users have complained about poor customer support. Additionally, MailChimp’s pricing plans are quite expensive, especially if you need advanced features such as automation and customer segmentation.
If you’re looking for a more affordable option, Constant Contact is a great choice. It offers many of the same features as MailChimp, but it’s much easier to use and has better customer support. Plus, it’s much more affordable, especially if you don’t need advanced features such as automation and customer segmentation.
Another popular option is Infusionsoft. It’s similar to Constant Contact in terms of pricing and features, but it has a few unique advantages. Ultimately, the best email marketing provider for your business will depend on your specific needs. If you’re just starting out in email marketing, MailChimp or Constant Contact are great options. A great email marketing provider will offer a wide range of features that make it easy to create and send effective email campaigns. Here are some of the most important features to look for:
A drag-and-drop email builder is essential for creating visually appealing campaigns that capture your readers’ attention. It should allow you to easily add images, videos, and other multimedia content.
Segmenting your list allows you to send targeted emails that are more likely to be opened and clicked on by your recipients. This feature is especially important if you have a large or diverse list of subscribers.
An autoresponder is a series of emails that are sent automatically to your subscribers after they sign up for your list. This feature allows you to nurture leads and turn them into customers.
Landing pages are webpages that you can use to promote your products or services. They should be easy to customize and have a high conversion rate.
An email marketing provider should offer a variety of email formats, such as newsletters, autoresponders, and landing pages. This will give you more options for how you can use your emails to promote your business.
Integrations are a great way to streamline your email marketing process. Look for providers that offer integrations with popular marketing automation platforms and CRM systems. This will make it easier for you to track your campaigns and manage your subscriber list.
A/B testing is a great way to improve the effectiveness of your email campaigns. Look for a provider that offers this feature so that you can test different email formats and see what works best for your audience.
A/B testing is a marketing technique that allows you to test two versions of a message to see which one performs better. You can use A/B testing to improve the performance of your emails by making sure that they are the most effective.
The process is simple: you create two versions of an email message and send them to a sample of your audience. You then compare the performance of the two versions, looking at things like open rates, click-through rates, and conversions.
A/B testing is a great way to improve the performance of your emails because it helps you to find out what works best for your audience. By testing different email formats and subject lines, you can see what resonates best with your audience and make sure that you’re sending emails that they’ll want to open and read.
When you’re considering A/B testing, it’s important to keep a few things in mind:
The sample size for your test should be large enough that you can be confident in the results.
You should use a control group to make sure that any differences in performance are not due to random chance.
You should give each version of the email a fair chance to perform well before making any conclusions about which one is better.
A/B testing can be a great way to improve the performance of your emails, but it’s important to do it right. By following these guidelines, you can ensure that your testing is successful and that you can make confident decisions about how to improve your email campaigns.

The best I’ve found is Protonmail.
I have the feeling that, at least in the US, Gmail is over-represented and maybe that explains some of the bias here, but I am still going with the recommendation of “the only truly private” email service, as quoted above by Gus.
And the privacy is really great. Gmail doesn’t give a crap about who you are. That’s not a bad thing, but it does affect the quality of the “product” they’re offering.
Thanks for the comments, Mark. I’ve updated the article to include Protonmail in the discussion!
As Gus says, I’ve never found any email service that really provides that much privacy. The best I’ve found is a combination of Tutanota (for sending emails) and Protonmail (for receiving).
I’m sorry, but the comments are not about the only “truly private” email service. The comments above are about the best email service. I’m sure that Gus and Gus, and others, would love to use a truly private email service. In fact, I suspect that Gus and Gus would love it to be true, but it is not. There are no truly private email services that are secure for business use. Even Protonmail and Tutanota have serious problems in this area. I’m sure that Gus and Gus would have no problem using these for personal use, however, and would recommend it.
It’s very clear now that the article was written by Gus.
I’m not sure what that means, exactly, but if it means that you’re saying I wrote the article in a manner that makes it look like the comments are about the best email service, I don’t think that’s true.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
Inbox zero is the most important, but many inboxes are still not there. Gmail has come a long way in this regard. For some time, I have relied solely on Gmail to manage my inbox. There are some new mail applications coming out that are even better, such as ProtonMail. In the end, everyone will have to choose for themselves.
When you’re checking your email, what is the most frustrating thing about Gmail, and what would you change to improve the experience?
Too many emails. Inbox Zero should be mandatory for everyone.
Is there a type of email you’re not receiving that you would like to get more of, such as emails from your local barista, the local dry cleaner, etc.?
No, that’s all in my phone and calendar.
When you’re checking your email, how many devices do you use? How many times a day?
Gmail on mobile
Gmail on desktop
Do you have more than one Gmail account? Do you use a Gmail alias?
No, it would only distract me.
Gmail offers some nice features for tracking emails and getting replies, but there’s no way to do this for emails sent in the past. If you could have one feature added to Gmail, what would it be?
A search function that allows me to see who has already seen my message.
How many hours per day do you spend checking email? On what devices?
Around 30 minutes on my smartphone and 10 minutes on my laptop.
Do you use any email add-ons or apps to help you organize or communicate better? If so, which ones?
Gmail’s labels feature, plus Calendly and Doodle.
When you’re checking your email, what is the most important thing that you look for?
Emails from friends and family.
What would you like to see more of in email messages?
What would you like to see less of in email messages?
A lot of spam!
When you’re checking your email, do you read it all? Or do you quickly scan through it? Why?
Quick scan, because I have a lot to do.
Do you reply to every email? Do you reply to every email on the first attempt? If so, what percentage of the time do you find yourself having to revise your email before sending?
I reply to every email on the first attempt because I usually have a lot to do. I almost never have to revise.
If you could change something about Gmail, what would it be?
Do you like using Gmail? Why or why not?
It works fine. I wish it didn’t show a lot of ads, though.
What one tip would you give to someone who is just starting to use Gmail?
Take the time to sort your emails.
Do you consider Gmail to be a secure email service? Why or why not?
I have no idea. I don’t think about these things when it comes to email.
What one thing would you change about Gmail to make it better?
I would make it more secure.
Do you think Gmail is easy to use?
It’s not very intuitive.
What do you think the future holds for email? How do you think the landscape will look 5 years from now?
E-mail will be even more important and will continue to be used as a primary communication method. It’s just a matter of time before the world moves to Gmail, which is the new standard.

There are several companies that excel at email security, but I'll mention two. The first is Google. You are probably already familiar with the company, as Google is one of the leaders in email security. But if you're not familiar with Google, here's a quick introduction. Google has been around since 1998, and it's one of the leading internet companies in the world. Google's email service is called Gmail, and it has over 1.5 billion users worldwide. Gmail offers several features that make it one of the best email services available.
The first is spam filtering. Spam is a major problem for many people, and it can be frustrating to sort through hundreds of emails every day. Gmail has a strong spam filter that can filter out most spam messages.
The second is email encryption. Email encryption is important because it ensures that your emails are private and secure. Gmail offers several different types of email encryption, so you can choose the one that best suits your needs.
The third is two-factor authentication. Two-factor authentication is a security feature that requires you to enter a code in addition to your password in order to log in to your account. This makes it harder for someone to hack into your account.
The fourth is virus protection. Viruses can be a major problem for email users, and Gmail offers virus protection that can help keep your inbox safe from malicious emails.
If you're looking for an email service with strong security features, Gmail is a great option.</s>

There are quite a few email providers that have been able to carve out their own unique niche in the market, especially since the advent of Gmail. Microsoft Outlook is a prime example of this. In the early days of email, Gmail was the undisputed king of email providers. Gmail was founded in 2004 by two Ph.D. students at Stanford University, and it quickly became the most popular email provider in the world. Gmail offered a unique blend of features that other email providers couldn't match. Gmail's searchable interface was a game-changer, and its 1GB of storage space was much more generous than other providers. Gmail's simplicity and ease of use also made it a favorite of users.
However, Gmail has faced some competition in recent years. Microsoft Outlook has made a concerted effort to improve its email service and has added some features that Gmail doesn't offer, such as calendar integration and mobile app support. And there are also a number of other email providers that have emerged as viable alternatives to Gmail. So, which one is the best?

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
Our customers are primarily looking for reliable email delivery and good performance and stability. Of course, they also expect to be able to easily find their messages among the spam. And it is very important for us that our email service providers (ESPs) can offer both.
With a wide range of ESPs in the market, how does Tipico differentiate between the various offerings?
The ESP should offer many useful functions. The most important thing for Tipico is to find the right ESP and the right balance between price and quality. The price is a very important issue because the service costs a lot of money. The quality of the service is also very important.
What were the most important criteria for evaluating email deliverability?
We found it very difficult to assess the quality of deliverability. It is difficult to determine how well a supplier’s ESP has been integrated. There were many cases where we found that a new ESP is integrated in an unstable manner. We had to make very critical decisions.
Did your ESP offer any additional or complementary services?
In addition to the deliverability service, the ESP should also offer further services. For example, the ESP has its own white lists and black lists, and should be able to work with the blacklists of third parties, such as Spamhaus.
How did you identify your ESP provider? What led you to make a decision?
The ESP we chose was recommended by another ESP, who had worked with us before. The second ESP also had very good reviews. And in the end, it was more the quality of the service than the price that made the decision.
How has this email delivery system worked out in terms of effectiveness and satisfaction?
The delivery service works very well. And our ESP is very stable.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
In my view, Gmail has the best overall email experience. This includes the best security features, best email organization, best email delivery, and best collaborative tools. I love how Gmail puts an emphasis on email security, making it a much safer and more private option than most other email services. I love that Gmail is integrated with other Google products, making it easy to organize your email and share files with colleagues and friends. Finally, I love that Gmail is constantly updated with new features, making it an even more reliable and convenient choice.
Do you prefer free or paid email services?
That depends on your needs and budget. Generally, I prefer free email services, as they often have more features and better security than paid services. I also find that paid email services tend to be more expensive and less reliable than free services, so if you can find a free service that meets your needs, it’s often the better option. However, if you need more advanced features or higher levels of security, then a paid email service may be a better choice. Ultimately, it’s important to do your research and choose the best option for your specific needs.
Is Gmail better than other email providers, such as Outlook, Yahoo Mail, or Apple Mail?
Gmail is definitely one of the better email providers out there. It’s free, it’s secure, it has excellent spam protection, and it offers great organizational features. However, it’s not necessarily better than other email providers like Outlook, Yahoo Mail, or Apple Mail. Each of these providers has its own strengths and weaknesses, so it really depends on your needs and preferences. Ultimately, the best email provider for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences, so it’s important to do your research and compare different options before making a decision.
What email service provider is best for business email?
That really depends on the specific needs of the business. However, in my opinion, the best email service provider for business email is G Suite (or Google Workspace, depending on your location). G Suite offers a range of features, including robust spam protection, strong encryption, and collaboration tools, making it a great option for businesses. It also offers great value for money, with plans starting at just $5 per user per month. Additionally, G Suite is easy to set up and use, making it a great choice for businesses of all sizes.
How do you handle spam in Gmail?
I handle spam in Gmail by using the built-in spam filtering tool. This tool uses artificial intelligence to detect and filter out spam emails, making it easy to stay safe and protect my inbox. I also regularly check my spam folder, deleting any emails that I don’t recognize or that look suspicious. Finally, I block any email addresses or domains that are sending me spam emails, making it easier to stay safe.
How do you deal with junk mail in Gmail?
I deal with junk mail in Gmail by using the filters and sorting options available. This includes using the spam filter, marking emails as spam, and archiving or deleting emails that are not important. I also regularly check my inbox for any suspicious or unfamiliar emails, and I never open any emails from unknown sources. Finally, I use the reporting features in Gmail to help Google identify and eliminate spam emails, making it easier to stay safe and protect my inbox.
Can you delete old emails in Gmail?
Yes, you can delete old emails in Gmail. To do so, open your Gmail inbox and select the email you want to delete. Once you’ve selected the email, click the three dots in the top right corner and select “Move to Trash”. This will move the email to the Trash folder, where it will remain for 30 days. After 30 days, the email will be permanently deleted from your account. If you need to keep an email for an extended period of time, you can also Archive it instead of Deleting it. Archived emails will remain in your account for as long as you like.
What is the Gmail algorithm for filtering spam and prioritizing emails?
The Gmail algorithm for filtering spam and prioritizing emails is a complex one that uses a variety of factors to determine which emails are likely to be spam and which are more important. Gmail uses machine learning and artificial intelligence to analyze emails, looking for things like the sender’s email address, the content of the email, and the context of the conversation. It also considers other factors, such as the sender’s reputation and the size of the email. Gmail uses this information to determine which emails are likely to be spam and which are more important, prioritizing the important emails and filtering out the spam.
What is the Gmail algorithm for filtering spam?
The Gmail algorithm for filtering spam is a complex system that uses a variety of factors to determine which emails are likely to be spam and which are more important. Gmail uses machine learning and artificial intelligence to analyze emails, looking for things like the sender’s email address, the content of the email, and the context of the conversation. It also considers other factors, such as the sender’s reputation and the size of the email. Gmail uses this information to determine which emails are likely to be spam and which are more important, filtering out the spam.
Do email providers have access to your emails?
Yes, email providers do have access to your emails. Email providers are required to abide by the laws of the country where they are located, and in many countries, they are required to store copies of your emails for a certain period of time. Additionally, email providers are required to share information about your emails with law enforcement agencies if requested. This means that your emails could be accessed by law enforcement officials in order to investigate criminal activity or other legal matters.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
I recently signed up for a free plan with EmailAnalysis.net. The software provides insight into spam complaints, domain ratings, inbox placement, and many other factors that can have a significant impact on the success of your email campaigns. It also offers an easy-to-use interface and reliable customer service.
The main disadvantage I encountered is the lack of customization options, as there is no way to personalize the reports or set up automated notifications.
What are the most important factors for you to consider when selecting an email marketing service, and what do you think are some of the most important features to look out for?
I personally recommend the following essential features:
1. A good email deliverability record
2. A robust spam filtering system
3. A reliable infrastructure for email delivery
4. Integration with third-party tools such as CRMs and shopping carts
5. Customizable email templates
6. Opt-in/out options for subscribers
What is your overall impression of the services you’ve used? Are you generally satisfied with the results you’ve seen so far, and do you have any advice for anyone who is thinking of signing up for one of these services in the future?
The services I’ve used have provided me with great results, but they can be quite expensive compared to other providers. I would recommend looking into the free plans available from some providers, such as SendGrid and MailChimp, as they offer good deliverability rates at no cost. If you’re looking for something more robust, however, you may want to invest in a paid plan with one of the larger providers.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
As for collaboration features, the tools are improving, but they are not yet where they should be. The collaboration features that you find in Gmail, Microsoft, Yahoo!, and the rest are mostly for internal collaboration within a single organization. The only one who is trying to do collaboration between multiple organizations, between public and private, is Google. And it's been very successful. There's another email provider that I like, not for its collaboration but for its inbox. It's called Mailbox. Mailbox is an Apple-only app. It is very simple and effective. You can set it up with all your other email providers, such as Gmail, Yahoo! Mail, and all the rest. And when I get an email, I have a choice of what I want to do with it. For example, I can read it now or read it later. If I have something to do with the email, I can add it to a task. If I need to get back to it later, I can archive it. I can delegate it to someone else. And I can use filters to move it somewhere else. I can use Mailbox to send emails. That is, I can create emails without using an email client. I can create an email using Mailbox, add a subject, attach a photo, and send it. But Mailbox is only available on the iPhone. It's not on Android. It's not on Windows, and it's not on the web. And I don't see it coming to the web or to Android any time soon. I'm sure that if Google decides to develop an email client that is as simple as Mailbox and as effective, they would be on the map immediately.
One last question: Can you share a little more detail about what you find most challenging in managing all your mailboxes?
Inbox organization is the biggest challenge. Every email provider provides a way of categorizing your emails. Gmail provides you with tabs, inbox rules, filters, labels, and all the rest. Yahoo! Mail provides you with folders. Microsoft provides you with folders. And so on. And these are great ways of grouping your emails. You can then move your emails from one folder to another, or even delete your emails from one folder and put it in another folder. And so on. But the problem is that you have all these emails in all these folders, and you have to be able to find them. And the only way you can find your emails is by keywords. This is how we were taught to organize our emails when we were in grade school. That is, when I want to find an email, I will go and search for keywords. That's not very practical. So if I am a manager who has thousands of emails, how do I know where to start? Do I start with my email from last week? Do I start with emails from last month? Do I start with emails from last year? Do I start with all my email from a certain email thread? So, how do I know where to start? This is what I call the inbox management challenge.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery? And why?
For our needs, Google is excellent. Gmail offers good organization, the possibility of collaborating via Google Docs, and a great user interface. In addition, Google does not use your data for its advertising.
Do you work in a small-to-medium-sized business or company?
Are your company’s IT personnel or specialists responsible for managing email accounts? If so, what do you find most helpful in this regard?
Our IT department has always been well prepared for this role. It’s not just about managing mailboxes but also about offering the appropriate security measures, such as encryption, to protect our data. As a rule, we take our own security measures as well.
Can you tell us what you consider the most important aspects for evaluating an email provider in the B2B sector?
The most important aspect is the reliability of the provider, which is why we do not outsource our email provision. In the B2B sector, the most important thing is the quality of service and reliability. The infrastructure and the quality of the provider matter, which is why I would not recommend outsourcing email provision.
How do you decide which features of an email provider to use?
Our needs are the guiding principle in our decision. We rely on Google for our email service.
Does your company have a cloud storage service (such as OneDrive or Dropbox) to share files among employees?
Yes. We use Google Drive, but not in an enterprise solution. In my opinion, OneDrive is a better cloud storage solution.
Can you recommend any email providers or services for other companies and businesses?
A friend of mine who works at another bank recommended Mailfence as a reliable email provider.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
It is always a pleasure to hear from you, and thanks for your continued interest in our email security solution. I appreciate your taking the time to respond to our survey; your input is an important part of our ability to continue to improve MailWasher and provide the best possible service for our customers.
I would like to congratulate you on your recent wedding! May you have a lifetime of happiness and joy together.
You raise some good points about the different email service providers, and I can see that you are still using Microsoft Outlook. Personally, I have used it in the past but I find the email service providers like Google and Gmail to be much better and easier to use. They tend to have more features and a more reliable infrastructure for email delivery.
However, I would like to point out that MailWasher is not limited to Outlook or any other specific email service provider. MailWasher can work with any email service provider that allows you to download emails directly from your server. This means that you can use MailWasher to protect your emails from viruses, spam, and other threats, regardless of the email service provider you use.
I encourage you to give MailWasher a try and see how it can help you to improve your email security and keep your inbox clean. If you have any questions or feedback, please don’t hesitate to contact me.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
In terms of deliverability, if you ask me, there are not so many providers that I can recommend with confidence. For example, I know from my personal experience that email from Mailchimp to Germany (where I currently live) sometimes takes several hours to reach the recipients.
One thing that I want to mention about email providers is to be really careful about using public email providers for important email communications with your clients. While some of them have their own “end-to-end” encryption for emails, I know from my experience that in case of Mailchimp, it is not as secure as I would like it to be. It would not hurt to add an additional layer of security on top of your email, for example, by using ProtonMail.
In terms of email inboxes and collaborative tools, we use Microsoft Outlook for our email communications. We just find it very practical, thanks to its smart features like the quick creation of reminders, a calendar, and contact storage.
When it comes to collaborative tools, we find Slack very efficient. It’s like having a chat with each member of your team, and thanks to its advanced filters, you can quickly focus on the most important issues. We also use Google Meet for audio and video meetings. The only downside of Google Meet is that there is no screen sharing feature yet.
Which tools do you rely on to boost your work and creativity?
As a creative person, I’m always interested in apps and tools that allow me to quickly generate ideas. That’s why I always keep track of all the new apps that come out on the market, especially those aimed at creative people.
For example, when I create posters, I like to use Canva. I think its templates are very well done and it allows me to quickly experiment with different designs. I also use Adobe Photoshop for posters and mockups, but for photo editing I prefer to use the mobile app Snapseed. It allows you to quickly edit your photos.
In general, I think the best tools for creative people are not necessarily the most popular or the most expensive. I often find that the simplest tools, such as Post-It notes, can be very helpful in terms of thinking outside the box.
What was the greatest challenge you faced in your business and how did you overcome it?
I think my biggest challenge so far is learning how to be more patient. I tend to be very impatient and I’m used to having things done as soon as possible. I find it difficult to wait.
A few years ago, I started learning to meditate and this helped me greatly. I try to meditate every day, even if it’s only for a few minutes. It allows me to think about things that bother me less and feel less frustrated by my impatience.
Are you more of an early bird or a night owl?
It depends. Sometimes I feel like a night owl, sometimes an early bird, and sometimes a cat. I can’t say that I have a particular rhythm in terms of time, but I do have a particular way of working that involves breaks. For example, I prefer to work from home rather than in the office because I can take a break when I need to. I’ll often just go for a walk or do some stretching exercises, and then get back to work feeling more relaxed and refreshed.
What is the best advice you have ever received, and what do you hope to pass on?
The best advice I ever received is that everything is not that important. This seems like a very simple thing to say, but it has helped me a lot.
I hope to pass on the advice of always learning and growing. I find that it’s important to be open to new things, to try new things, and to keep learning. I also think it’s important to be honest with yourself and to always try to be the best you can be.
What is your biggest motivation in your life?
My biggest motivation is to learn new things. I love learning about new topics, new languages, and new cultures. I find it very motivating to learn and to grow. I think it’s also very motivating to be around people who are excited to learn new things.
What makes you a good designer?
I think I’m a good designer because I’m able to see things from different angles. I can take a step back from a project and look at it from a distance. I can also look at the project from different perspectives.
I’m a good designer because I can see the big picture and I can focus on the details. I’m a good designer because I can see the future of the project.
What is the most inspiring thing you’ve ever read or heard?
I think the most inspiring thing I’ve ever read or heard is the story of Einstein’s theory of relativity. I think it’s very inspiring because it shows how even the most simple things can have a big impact.
What is the most inspiring thing you’ve ever seen?
The most inspiring thing I’ve ever seen is a sunset. I find it very inspiring to see the sun setting. It reminds me that there is beauty in the world.
I’m inspired by the people who are passionate about what they do. I’m inspired by the people who are always learning and growing. I’m inspired by the people who are always striving to be the best they can be.
I’m inspired by the people who are willing to help others. I’m inspired by the people who are kind and generous. I’m inspired by the people who are positive and optimistic. I’m inspired by the people who are happy and grateful.
What is the most important lesson you’ve learned in life?
I think the most important lesson I’ve learned in life is that things don’t always go as planned. I think it’s important to be open to new things and to be flexible. I think it’s important to be able to adapt to new situations.
What is your favorite quote and why?
My favorite quote is “Everything is possible” because it reminds me that I can always do better and that I can always do more.

If I had to give a speech for five minutes on any topic, I would choose the topic of mental health. I think it’s very important to talk about mental health because it’s something that affects everyone.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
In a world of overcrowded email inboxes, it is hard to find an email client that not only allows you to organize your messages but also offers a reliable infrastructure for email delivery.
However, there are a few email providers that stand out in terms of deliverability, privacy, and collaborative features. Gmail, Outlook, Yahoo Mail, and Fastmail are among them.
Gmail is a cloud-based email service that has quickly become one of the world's most popular web-based email services. It is a part of Google's suite of web-based apps, which also includes the well-known Google Docs, Google Sheets, and Google Slides.
The email service comes with a slew of features to aid users in managing their emails and collaborating with other individuals. For starters, it enables the creation of multiple email addresses for various tasks, which can be used to separate work and personal email accounts. Gmail also allows users to chat with other users right from their inbox. You can do this without leaving your inbox and by adding a simple Google Chat icon in the sidebar.
Google has also made its email service more private. Users can now have two-factor authentication enabled, which adds an extra layer of security to their accounts. They can also create a Google Sign-In option for others to sign in to their accounts.
Additionally, they can add a security key, which adds another layer of protection. These features enable Gmail users to keep their emails safe and secure.
Additionally, the email service provides users with the option of having their email automatically deleted after a certain period of time. The option is available for both the web and mobile app versions of Gmail.
Aside from that, Gmail offers various features such as Smart Compose, which lets users compose emails with suggestions based on the text they enter in the text box.
Another one is Smart Reply, which offers suggestions based on the context of the conversation. This is helpful as it reduces the number of emails users have to write.
Moreover, Google's search-driven technology helps to reduce the number of spam emails users receive. To ensure the safety and security of its users' emails, Gmail scans all emails and filters out spam, phishing, and other malicious messages.
Overall, Gmail is a reliable and user-friendly email service that can help users organize their inboxes and stay on top of their emails. With its extensive features, it provides a secure and reliable way for users to manage their emails.
Outlook, one of the most popular email services, stands out for its advanced features, including the ability to add multiple email accounts, send and receive large files, create shared calendars, and customize the user interface. With its intuitive interface, users can quickly locate their emails and files, saving them time.
With Outlook, users can create personal or shared calendars to keep track of events and tasks. The email service also allows users to add events to the shared calendar and send notifications to remind others of upcoming events. This is a useful feature, especially for busy professionals and organizations.
Outlook is also designed to be user-friendly, making it easy for even novice users to get started quickly. Users can simply create an account and begin sending and receiving emails.
Another important feature of Outlook is its built-in spam protection, which automatically filters out unwanted emails and protects users from malicious links and attachments. With Outlook's spam protection, users can rest assured that their inbox will be free from unwanted messages.
Outlook also has advanced search features, allowing users to quickly find emails or attachments. The advanced search feature enables users to search emails by keywords, sender, date, and other criteria.
Users can also use Outlook's message flags to quickly identify and respond to important emails. Outlook's message flags are a useful feature, especially for busy professionals who receive a lot of emails.
Overall, Outlook is a reliable and user-friendly email service that offers advanced features to make managing emails and organizing calendars easier. Whether you are a business owner, student, or individual, Outlook is an ideal email service for organizing your emails and calendars.
Yahoo Mail is an email service that has been in existence since the early days of the Internet. It has since grown to become one of the most popular email services, with over 225 million active users. Yahoo Mail is a great option for people who want to organize their email inbox. It comes with a number of features to help users manage their emails, such as the ability to create folders, mark emails as important, and view emails in conversation view.
Yahoo Mail also has advanced search options that make it easy to find emails, attachments, or contacts. Users can search for emails based on the sender, the recipient, the subject, and even the body of the message. Yahoo Mail also provides a handy filter that lets users set up email notifications, which can be a great way to stay on top of important emails without having to check your inbox every few minutes.
Yahoo Mail also provides users with advanced email settings that allow them to customize the layout, choose the number of emails to display per page, and set up filters to block certain types of emails from coming into their inbox.
The email service also has advanced spam protection features to help users avoid unsolicited emails. Users can set up filters to block emails from certain senders, and Yahoo Mail also provides a spam folder that users can view to catch spam emails that have made their way into their inbox.
In addition, Yahoo Mail provides users with advanced email encryption and security features to keep their emails and data safe. Yahoo Mail offers two-factor authentication, as well as the option to encrypt emails with PGP. This makes it difficult for hackers to access sensitive information.
Overall, Yahoo Mail is a great option for people who want to organize their email inbox and keep their data safe. With advanced search options, advanced email settings, and advanced spam protection, Yahoo Mail provides users with all the features they need to stay on top of their emails.
Fastmail, an email provider that offers an innovative solution for organizing emails, has recently released its newest feature, Fastmail Sync.
Fastmail Sync allows users to sync emails and contacts from multiple devices. Users can choose to sync from any email address or device they have registered with Fastmail, which makes it easy to access emails and contacts from any device.
In addition, Fastmail Sync offers advanced features such as the ability to schedule messages, set reminders, and categorize emails into folders.
With Fastmail Sync, users can quickly and easily access emails from multiple devices, as well as categorize and organize emails and contacts in a convenient and efficient way.
The new Fastmail Sync feature is available for all Fastmail users. To enable the feature, users simply need to select the option in their Fastmail account settings.
Overall, Fastmail Sync is a great solution for those looking to stay organized and on top of their emails and contacts. With its advanced features, users can quickly and easily access emails and contacts from multiple devices, as well as categorize and organize them in a convenient and efficient way.

Fastmail is built on the same technology that powers Google Mail, ensuring that your email is safe and secure.
Fastmail's encryption is based on industry-leading technology and uses Perfect Forward Secrecy, which ensures that your emails remain secure even if the key is ever compromised.

Additionally, Fastmail has a zero-knowledge policy, which means that they do not access or store your emails, meaning they cannot be compelled to share them with law enforcement.
Fastmail also offers advanced email security features, such as malware and spam protection, to keep your inbox safe from malicious emails and unwanted messages.

We have a dedicated team of engineers who test each mail service provider to ensure the best possible results. In terms of our deliverability results, we recommend 3 services: Protonmail, Posteo, and Fastmail.
We use the “spam score” as a measure to rate email providers. There are a few services with a spam score of 100, which is considered perfect.
What do you consider to be the most important features to look out for when choosing a new email provider?
When it comes to choosing a mail provider, the following features should be considered:
1) Anti-spam (as in, is it good enough to reach your inbox?)
2) Encryption/end-to-end encryption (does it offer PGP or S/MIME encryption? Does the provider offer self-signing certificates?)
3) Price (if it’s too expensive, no one will switch)
4) Inbox management (is it easy to organize your emails? Is it easy to create new folders? Can you filter incoming emails? How can you quickly archive/delete emails? Does it integrate with other services like Slack, Dropbox, etc.)
5) Email forwarding (do you like to receive emails via your phone? Then choose an email provider that offers a mobile app and forwarding to other email accounts)
What’s your recommendation on email service providers for those who value user privacy and security above everything else?
Our current favorite is Protonmail. They offer a very good email encryption service, but their prices have gone up quite a bit lately and are becoming rather expensive. If you are on a tight budget, try Posteo or Fastmail.
Protonmail has been under heavy DDoS attack and their servers are not really reliable these days. Posteo has been tested by independent providers with a spam score of 100.

When you start using an email service provider, it’s important to understand how they work. If you want to get the most out of your email provider, you need to understand how it works.
Email providers work by using a system called “pulling”. Pulling is when the email provider sends you an email and then asks you to reply with a message. If you reply to the email, the email provider will send it to your email account.
If you don’t reply to the email, the email provider will not send it to your email account. This means that you need to reply to emails from your email provider or you won’t get any emails from them.
