<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
A few stand out:
Google's Inbox: With the Inbox, the G-men have found the right formula for the mobile age - it is fast, clean and has some nifty features, such as reminders and snoozing. Its downfall is its inability to filter out spam, especially from Chinese and other Eastern European countries.
Apple's Mail: This is a bit of a surprise, I know. But we use Apple Mail for our personal email accounts at our company, and it is great at the essentials: organization and message delivery. Its real-time push notifications are a plus, although I'd prefer for it to provide a "read later" option to avoid inbox clutter.
Zoho Mail: I'm not a fan of Zoho Mail's look-and-feel, but it does have some great features. I particularly appreciate its focus on privacy and how well it manages your time spent checking emails. And it is incredibly fast and reliable.
Microsoft Outlook: It has improved a lot, but not to the point where it can challenge Google and Apple. I don't have a problem with the Microsoft email client for business users, but for consumers, it needs a few more updates.</s>

I’m in favor of providers with a strong commitment to user privacy. We’ve found that some of the biggest providers don’t prioritize privacy at all, or they claim to prioritize privacy while secretly selling the data they collect to other companies. Even those that claim to value privacy sometimes have their own reasons to sell user data (think about the amount of targeted advertising they have to show you to stay profitable).
For example, Proton Mail is a service I’d recommend to anyone, but I know that it’s been criticized for not being a fully private provider, which isn’t necessarily true. They encrypt your emails and can’t read them, but they do keep your account information in plain text on their servers. This is a security risk, as your password could be stolen from them, but it’s not really a privacy issue. Still, it’s an easy-to-understand way that Proton Mail isn’t completely private like some other providers.
Proton Mail is also criticized for allegedly selling ads, which isn’t true. They do sell ads, but it’s on a small scale, and it’s a side business for them. Their main business is the paid plans that customers buy, not the ads.
So, in conclusion, I recommend Proton Mail because it’s a great service for email, but be aware that it isn’t completely private, and they do sell ads (though it’s not their main business).
What is your advice for anyone who wants to set up a private email account and wants to be anonymous online? What tools should they use, and what should they avoid?
One way to set up an anonymous email account is to use the Tor Browser Bundle (TBB). The TBB is a free tool that allows you to browse the Internet with Tor, a tool that hides your IP address and keeps your identity hidden.
When you use Tor, your Internet traffic is encrypted and directed through a network of volunteer-run servers around the world. This makes it harder for your Internet service provider (ISP) or anyone else to know where you’re going on the Internet.
With Tor, you can browse the Internet anonymously. It works by bouncing your Internet traffic through a network of volunteer-run servers around the world. This makes it hard for your ISP or anyone else to track your activities online.
Another option is to use a VPN (Virtual Private Network). VPNs encrypt your Internet traffic and route it through a server in another location, making it harder for anyone to see what you’re doing online.
If you’re not sure how to set up an anonymous email account, or if you’re looking for a more secure solution, you can always contact a professional hacker for assistance.

Another important thing you can do is encrypt your emails. This will help make sure that your emails are only read by the person you’re sending them to.

What is the most reliable email server?
We are often asked what the best email server is. Unfortunately, there is no one-size-fits-all answer to this question as different email providers will suit different users. Some of the most popular email servers include Microsoft Exchange, G Suite, and Zimbra. However, it is important to remember that each email server has its own unique features and functionality, so it is essential to choose the one that best meets your needs.
There are many different email servers available on the market, but which one is the most reliable? Unfortunately, there is no simple answer to this question as it depends on a number of factors. However, in general, Microsoft Exchange and G Suite are considered to be the most reliable email servers.

G Suite is another popular email server that is used by many businesses and organizations around the world. It is well-known for its reliability and security, and it offers a number of features that make it ideal for business use.
Which email system is the most secure?
There are many different types of email systems, and each one has its own security features. However, it is generally agreed that the most secure email system is one that uses end-to-end encryption.
End-to-end encryption means that the message is encrypted as it is sent from the sender to the recipient. This means that even if someone were to intercept the message, they would not be able to read it because they would not have the encryption key.
There are a number of different email systems that use end-to-end encryption, including Gmail, Yahoo Mail, and Microsoft Outlook. However, not all of them are equally secure. Gmail, for example, only uses end-to-end encryption for some of its messages.
Overall, the best way to ensure that your emails are secure is to use an email system that uses end-to-end encryption. This will give you the best possible protection against hackers and other malicious actors.

2. Microsoft Exchange email servers
Microsoft Exchange email servers are also very secure. They use encryption to protect your emails, and they have a number of security features that help to prevent hacking and other attacks.
3. G Suite email servers
G Suite email servers are also very secure. They use encryption to protect your emails, and they have a number of security features that help to prevent hacking and other attacks.
4. Apple Mail email servers
Apple Mail email servers are also very secure. They use encryption to protect your emails, and they have a number of security features that help to prevent hacking and other attacks.

Which email provider is best for privacy?
Email is one of the most important ways we communicate with others, but there are many different ways to send and receive emails, each with its own set of pros and cons. In this article, we'll explore the different ways to send and receive emails, as well as the privacy implications of each option.
First, let's take a look at the different ways to send emails. There are two main ways to send emails:
1. You can use a traditional email client like Outlook or Gmail.
2. You can use a web-based email service like Gmail or Yahoo Mail.
When using a traditional email client, your emails are stored on your computer and you control who can access them. However, if your computer is hacked or lost, your emails could be compromised.
With a web-based email service, your emails are stored on the email provider's servers and you don't control who can access them. However, if the email provider's servers are hacked or lost, your emails could be compromised.
So which email provider is best for privacy? That depends on your needs. If you need to control who has access to your emails, then using a traditional email client is probably the best option. If you don't need to control who has access to your emails, then using a web-based email service is probably the best option.</s>

To give you the answers to your questions, we have talked to 25 email marketing and product managers, email service providers, and other experts in the email industry, who have been using Gmail, Mailchimp, Outlook, Sendgrid, and Zoho Mail to send email marketing campaigns, manage internal emails, and build their email list.
The interviewees came from the United States, United Kingdom, India, and Romania.

2. Why are so many email experts switching to Zoho Mail?
1. 100% deliverability
According to Aparna Bala, Head of Growth Marketing at Mailchimp, Gmail has been her go-to email service provider for years.
"One of the main reasons I always preferred Gmail is that I knew it was a 100% deliverability rate. If you're going to pay money to an ESP, it's a little unnerving to know that you can't guarantee deliverability for your customers. And if they're not able to deliver, what happens next?"
With 800 million active monthly users, Gmail is the most popular free email service in the world. However, it is known to have issues with its deliverability rate.
Some email marketing companies, such as Mailchimp and Sendgrid, have an automated feature that lets you know if your emails don't reach your customers' inbox.
If the ESP you're using cannot deliver your emails to your subscribers' inboxes, then your messages will end up in spam or in the bulk folder. Gmail's average inbox placement rate is 69.1%, while its average spam rate is 27.4%.
If your emails are being marked as spam by Gmail, you might consider migrating to another email service provider. Aparna shared that she recently switched to Zoho Mail, which had a 98% deliverability rate for her and her team.
2. Full-fledged email marketing tools
Aparna also said that she likes the free features of Gmail. For example, she can schedule emails and create email sequences.
However, if you want to send more than 1,500 emails a day, you will need to upgrade to G Suite, which starts at $5 per user per month.
The Gmail suite also offers advanced features such as a landing page builder and ad creator. In contrast, Zoho Mail doesn't have these features.
Aparna pointed out that while Zoho Mail is known as an email service provider, it's much more than that.
"We use Zoho Mail for both internal email and marketing. So I would say the marketing automation tools were really easy to set up, and we're happy with the deliverability and customer support," said Aparna.
She added that her team also likes the user migration feature, which lets you import your email contacts into Zoho Mail.
3. Easy user migration
One of the reasons why Zoho Mail is the preferred email service provider for many Gmail users is its migration feature.
For example, Tanya Kachak, a Senior Marketing Manager at Freshworks, migrated from Gmail to Zoho Mail a few years ago. Her team of 20 was already using Zoho CRM for managing leads and customers, so it made sense to migrate to Zoho Mail as well.
Zoho Mail comes with a feature called Team Migration, which lets you import up to 50 email addresses from other email service providers.
Tanya explained, "The most recent email migration we've done was in 2019, when we moved from Gmail to Zoho. For this migration, Zoho offered a free migration option. We were able to migrate all the important emails with zero disruption."
4. A free version for teams up to 25 users
According to Tanya, Zoho Mail is one of the few email service providers that offer a free version for teams up to 25 users.
"The free version offers unlimited email storage and team inboxes. You can also migrate up to 50 email addresses per year."
If you're looking for a free email service that offers more than just 15 GB of storage, then you should consider Zoho Mail. It is one of the few email providers that offer unlimited storage.
Here are some other email service providers that offer unlimited storage:
Hootsuite - up to 5 users
Microsoft Office 365 - up to 5 users
Aparna also pointed out that while Zoho Mail doesn't have the same email deliverability as Gmail, it's still better than other free email providers.
The reason is that Zoho Mail has a better infrastructure for email delivery, which means that your emails will be delivered to your customers' inboxes.
"We used to use Zoho Mail for email marketing. It was a good option for us because it was less expensive than other email service providers, and it was easy to use. However, when we tried to migrate to another ESP, we found that there were some challenges," said Aparna.
According to her, one of the biggest challenges she faced while migrating from Gmail to Zoho Mail was not being able to export her emails.
"Zoho Mail was good, but it was very difficult to migrate from it. When we wanted to migrate to another ESP, we found that the process was complicated and time-consuming. And I think that's why some people are hesitant to migrate from Zoho Mail to other email service providers."
Aparna explained that she tried to export her emails from Zoho Mail but found that she couldn't export them.
"I tried to export my emails from Zoho Mail, but I found that I couldn't export them. The email was just in there and I couldn't do anything with it. This is a problem because when you're using a free email service, you don't want to have to keep all your emails on the server. You want to be able to export them and save them to your hard drive."
According to Aparna, this is not a problem with other email service providers, such as Microsoft Outlook.
"The difference with Outlook is that you can export your emails. You can create a PST file that contains all of your emails, and then you can export it to a hard drive. This makes it easy to move your emails from one computer to another or to a different email service provider."
This is a common problem that many email users have experienced. For example, Gmail was recently found to have a bug that prevents you from exporting your emails.

What's next for the email marketing industry?
There is no doubt that the email marketing industry is constantly evolving. With the rise of new technologies and the increasing demand for personalized customer experiences, email marketers must stay up-to-date with the latest trends.
One of the biggest trends in email marketing is personalization. Personalization is the process of tailoring the content and design of emails to specific customers' preferences.
This can include using customer data to target specific audiences or using artificial intelligence to create personalized content.
Personalization has been proven to increase engagement and conversion rates. So if you're looking to improve your email marketing strategy, you should definitely consider implementing personalization.
Another trend that is becoming more popular is using video in email campaigns. Video can be a powerful tool for communicating your message and engaging your customers.
Video can also be used to showcase products or services, or to provide educational content.
If you're not already using video in your email marketing campaigns, you should definitely consider doing so.
The rise of chatbots and automation is also an important trend to keep an eye on. Chatbots are computer programs that simulate human conversation. They can be used to provide customer support, take orders, or answer questions.
Automation is the use of technology to automate repetitive tasks. This can include using email automation tools to create and send emails, or using CRM software to track customer data.
Chatbots and automation can help you save time and money while improving the customer experience. If you're not already using chatbots or automation in your email marketing campaigns, you should definitely consider doing so.
The rise of voice assistants is another trend that email marketers should keep an eye on. Voice assistants are computer programs that use natural language processing to understand and respond to voice commands.
Voice assistants can be used to control smart home devices, order products online, or get information about your favorite sports team.
The use of voice assistants is on the rise, and email marketers should start thinking about how they can use voice assistants to improve their email marketing campaigns.
Finally, we're seeing more and more brands using mobile-first design. This means that they're designing their emails with mobile devices in mind.
This is important because more and more people are using mobile devices to access their email accounts. If your emails don't look good on mobile devices, you could be losing out on a lot of potential customers.
If you're not already using mobile-first design in your email marketing campaigns, you should definitely consider doing so.
All of these trends have the potential to improve your email marketing campaigns, so it's important to stay up-to-date on them.

Gmail is an email provider that has been widely used by businesses, individuals, and organizations for many years. However, the platform has recently undergone several significant updates that have improved its functionality, performance, and security.
One of the most notable updates to Gmail is the introduction of Smart Compose, a feature that helps users compose emails more efficiently. Smart Compose uses machine learning algorithms to suggest complete sentences and phrases as you type, making it easier for you to express your thoughts and ideas in a more professional and polished manner.
Another major update to Gmail is the new priority inbox feature, which helps users manage their email more effectively. The priority inbox automatically sorts incoming emails into categories, such as “Important,” “Unread,” and “Promotions,” making it easier to find the messages that require your immediate attention.
In addition to these updates, Gmail has also introduced a new design that features a cleaner, more modern look. The platform now includes a left sidebar that provides quick access to frequently used features, such as the ability to schedule emails, create meetings, and set reminders.
Overall, the recent updates to Gmail have significantly improved the functionality, performance, and security of the platform. With its improved Smart Compose feature, priority inbox, and new design, Gmail is an excellent choice for those who want to stay organized and productive when communicating through email.

If you were to choose only one email provider, which would it be?
The poll on the subject was conducted among the users of the EmailOnAcid newsletter. In total, there were 666 respondents from the US, UK, and Australia.
Both Gmail and Outlook are quite even in popularity. Gmail wins with 39%, while Outlook has 38%.
The biggest advantage of Outlook is the organization of your inbox, but it’s also highly appreciated by users for its great filtering and spam blocking features.
When it comes to Gmail, it’s hard to ignore the 15 GB of free storage it offers. Gmail also has good privacy protection and a handy built-in chat tool for teams.
The biggest drawback for both of these services is the lack of support for POP or IMAP.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery? In other words, which email service provider (ESP) is currently the best in terms of overall user satisfaction?
We're not affiliated with any ESP, nor do we conduct in-house research and offer our own conclusions. Instead, we rely on independent research results for the best Email Service Providers and Marketing Automation Tools.
As you probably already know, our research methodology includes a 60-question survey that covers both B2C and B2B brands.
We conduct the survey twice a year to gauge the overall satisfaction with current email marketing providers and identify the top performers.
The results were then compared with the survey conducted in the second quarter of 2018 to identify the trends in the industry and the most popular providers for both types of brands.
As the results of our recent study show, the satisfaction rate with email marketing platforms remains unchanged. The top three providers are the same as they were in 2018. The difference is that now HubSpot comes first, with Mailchimp close behind.
In the fourth quarter of 2018, 88.7% of the respondents were satisfied with their current email provider, which was an increase of 0.7% compared to the second quarter of the same year.
HubSpot and Mailchimp were the clear leaders with 93.1% and 89.7% satisfaction, respectively. Constant Contact, SendinBlue, and Gmail followed behind with 88.3%, 86.3%, and 85.1% satisfaction rates.
In addition to the satisfaction rate, our research also focuses on the most popular providers based on the total number of respondents.
With 39.2% of total respondents, HubSpot is still the most popular email marketing provider among B2B businesses, closely followed by Mailchimp (35.7%).
As for the B2C brands, HubSpot and Mailchimp share the first place with 36.1% and 35.5% satisfaction rates, respectively.
With the help of our detailed email marketing survey, you can find out more about your subscribers, their preferences, and buying behaviors.
To find out more, download our research findings.
How to choose the right email marketing tool?
When you decide to take your email marketing campaign to the next level and choose a new tool, the research process becomes quite complicated. The sheer number of providers can be overwhelming, to say the least.
If you can't decide which one to pick, follow the guide below to find the tool that will meet your business goals.
1. Define your needs. Are you looking for a full-service email marketing provider or do you need a tool that will help you manage your existing subscriber list? If your requirements are simple, we recommend starting with a free tool like Mailchimp. If you need more advanced features like advanced segmentation and A/B testing, you should pick Constant Contact, Drip, or HubSpot.
2. Decide what you want to achieve with your email campaigns. Before you choose an email provider, make sure you know what you want to accomplish with your campaigns. Maybe you want to engage your subscribers with personalized content, boost your open rates, or improve your deliverability. If your goals are simple and you need an email marketing tool for personal use, Mailchimp is an excellent option. However, if you want a platform that will help you scale your email marketing, we recommend Constant Contact or Drip.
3. Compare email providers. Now you know what you want to achieve with your email marketing, so it's time to compare the tools that can help you do it. Take a look at their pricing plans, available features, and integrations, and don't forget to find out about the pros and cons. Remember that Mailchimp, ActiveCampaign, and Constant Contact have a free plan available. If you don't want to pay, you can use it to gain experience and understand if email marketing is something you want to invest in.
4. Pick the best tool for your needs. Now that you know which features and pricing plans to look for, you can compare the providers and choose the one that matches your requirements. You can also try the free version to find out if you like the platform and want to continue using it.
If you're still unsure which tool to pick, check out our detailed email marketing guide.

Why email marketing is essential to business
While social media is great for building your brand and keeping customers engaged, email is your most direct marketing line to your customers. You know where they are, what they do, and how to reach them. You can engage with them wherever they are.
In the email marketing industry, the term ROI (Return on Investment) is used to express the monetary benefits of using email marketing. If you are using email marketing, you can expect ROI of up to 25:1. This means that for every dollar you spend on email marketing, you can expect to earn $25 back.
If you're new to the email marketing industry, you may be wondering what this means. So let's take a closer look.
Email marketing is a powerful tool. It can help you increase sales, build customer relationships, and engage with your audience in a personalized way. And the ROI is incredible!
The ROI of email marketing
The ROI (Return on Investment) of email marketing is incredible. It's estimated that you can earn back $25 for every dollar you spend on email marketing.
This means that if you spend $100 on email marketing, you can expect to earn $2,500 in return.
That's a huge return on investment!
There are a few reasons why email marketing has such a high ROI. First, email is a personal medium. When someone receives an email from a company, they're more likely to engage with it than if they were to receive a generic email.
Second, email is a direct medium. When someone clicks on a link in an email, they're taken directly to the website where they can make a purchase.
Finally, email is an efficient medium. A person can read an email in a matter of seconds, whereas a website might take several minutes to load.
If you're not using email marketing yet, now is the time to start. It's an inexpensive way to reach a large audience, and the ROI is unbeatable.
Benefits of email marketing for your business
There are a number of benefits to using email marketing for your business.
For starters, email is a great way to build relationships with your customers. By staying in touch and keeping your customers informed about your products and services, you can show them that you care and that you're committed to helping them.
Second, email marketing is a great way to drive traffic to your website. When you send out an email campaign, you can include links to your website and encourage your subscribers to visit. This can help to increase brand awareness and drive more traffic to your website.
Finally, email marketing can help you to generate leads and sales. When you use email marketing effectively, you can attract new customers and convert them into sales.
Why you should be using email marketing
Email marketing is one of the most cost-effective ways to reach a large audience. Not only is it a great way to build relationships with your customers, but it's also a powerful tool for driving traffic to your website and generating leads and sales.
Plus, it's easy to get started and it's relatively simple to track your results.
If you're not already using email marketing, now is the time to start. With so many benefits, it's a great way to grow your business.
What you need to know about email marketing
In order to have a successful email marketing campaign, you need to understand a few key things.
First, you need to have a strategy. What are you trying to achieve with your campaign? Are you trying to build brand awareness? Drive traffic to your website? Generate leads? Once you know your goal, you can start to put together a plan.
Second, you need to segment your audience. Not everyone on your list is going to be interested in your products or services. So, you need to segment your list into different groups based on their interests.
Third, you need to create engaging content. Your emails need to be interesting and relevant to your audience. They should also include a call-to-action, which is a specific instruction that tells the recipient what action you want them to take.
Fourth, you need to monitor your results. Once you've sent out your emails, it's important to track their performance. Are people opening your emails? Clicking on your links? Making purchases? By monitoring your results, you can make adjustments to your campaign as needed.
Email marketing can be a powerful tool for businesses of all sizes. However, it's important to have a plan and to measure your results. By following these tips, you can create a successful email marketing campaign.

After you've segmented your list, you can start to create email content. The content should be relevant to your audience and should include a clear call to action. The call to action should tell your audience what you want them to do next.
Once you've created your content, you can start to send emails. The frequency of your emails will depend on your strategy. You may send one email a week or one email a month. The key is to make sure that you're sending emails at a frequency that works for your audience.

There are a few reasons why email marketing is so important. First, it's a very effective way to reach a large audience. With email marketing, you can reach a much larger number of people than you would with other marketing channels, such as social media or print advertising.
Second, email marketing is a very affordable way to reach your audience. The cost of sending an email campaign is usually much lower than the cost of other marketing channels.
Third, email marketing is a very targeted way to reach your audience. You can send emails to specific segments of your audience, which means that you're only paying for the ads that you actually want to see.
Email marketing is a powerful tool for businesses. It can be used to generate leads, drive sales, and build relationships with customers. If you're not already using email marketing, now is the time to start. With so many benefits, it's a great way to grow your business.</s>

I was able to gain valuable insights into this question by speaking to our two guests, who are deeply involved in developing and improving their respective email providers:
Marcus Müller from Mailbox.org
Mailbox.org is a mailbox provider that emphasizes the highest possible standard of data protection.
The provider has already won several awards for its security standards. It is an independent company based in Switzerland, which operates its own data center. The company has a strong focus on GDPR-compliant data processing.
The second guest is Dr. Markus Jähnichen from Fasthosts.
The British Fasthosts has been a reliable email provider since the nineties. Fasthosts has been acquired by the United Internet Group, which also owns GMX, the second email provider we talked to. Both providers have a large customer base and extensive features.
What is your email provider of choice? We would love to hear from you!
Tips from the experts: Inbox organization
A good overview of your email accounts can be a challenge – whether they are work emails, personal emails, or a mixture of the two. A well-organized inbox is the key to better email management and helps you to focus on what really matters.
According to both Marcus and Markus, there are some helpful tools that can help you get a better overview of your email inbox.
The “label” function allows you to create custom labels for your emails. These can help you categorize emails by topic, date, or priority. This makes it easier for you to quickly find relevant emails.
Spam and Phishing Protection
With the help of spam filters, your email inbox can be sorted automatically and you can get an idea of which emails belong together. This helps you to identify unwanted or unsolicited emails that you do not want to read in your inbox.
Within your mailbox you can also apply a filter so that you receive your emails in a certain order. There is the option to set filters by:
Day of the week (Monday – Friday)
You can also use a so-called “Folding” function. This is a tool that allows you to organize your emails in an orderly way and only display relevant emails in your inbox. Emails that don’t need to be opened are placed in a secondary inbox folder where you can find them later.
In summary, both our experts emphasize the importance of a well-organized inbox as the first step towards better email management. This includes tools like the label function, spam and phishing protection, and filters that allow you to sort your emails in a structured way.
How are your email inboxes organized? We would love to hear from you!
Tips from the experts: Collaboration tools
Working together can be very efficient. Unfortunately, communication often remains unstructured and time-consuming.
Our guests also emphasize the importance of good collaboration tools for efficient email management. In this context, both providers emphasize the role of “teams” within the collaboration tools.
Mailbox.org’s collaborative tool is called “Mailbox.org Teams”. This is available for both free and paid accounts. With this tool, you can create different team structures to organize your work and structure your collaboration.
Team members can be assigned different roles, and individual team members can be restricted in their access rights. This makes it easier for team members to get a clear overview of their tasks and stay organized.
“Mailbox.org Teams” is especially suitable for small and medium-sized enterprises that want to create a shared workspace for their employees. This allows everyone to work together more effectively.
Fasthosts Email and Hosting also offers the “Office 365 Business” solution for collaboration and communication. The service can be used on all devices and allows collaboration within teams.
Fasthosts Email and Hosting offers a variety of tools for efficient email management, such as mailboxes, spam and phishing protection, and collaboration tools.
In summary, both providers emphasize the importance of collaboration tools for more efficient email management. This can include the use of teams within the provider and the use of collaboration tools like Microsoft Teams.
Tips from the experts: Privacy settings
In the digital age, it is more important than ever to protect your data. Both email providers offer you a high level of data protection.
Marcus Müller from Mailbox.org emphasizes the importance of choosing a provider that offers maximum protection. In his view, the focus should be on the Swiss company “SwissDNS” and its strict GDPR compliance.
SwissDNS offers high-quality encryption, making it impossible for hackers to access your data. In addition, SwissDNS has its own data centers, which means that all data stays in Switzerland. This makes it much more difficult for other countries to access your data.
Markus Jähnichen from Fasthosts points out that email security has always been a central pillar of Fasthosts’ activities. All of their email services are protected by SpamExperts, a leading spam-filtering solution. In addition, their email services are protected by a powerful DDoS-protection system, which ensures the stability of email traffic.
In summary, both providers emphasize the importance of choosing a provider that offers maximum data protection.
How secure is your email data? We would love to hear from you!
Tips from the experts: Reliable email delivery
The reliability of email delivery is of great importance in modern email communication. This is true for both small and large businesses.
According to Markus, Fasthosts offers the “MX Routing” option, which guarantees 100% delivery reliability. In addition, Fasthosts offers a “Growth-Protection” package that is specially tailored to companies that have to deal with huge amounts of incoming and outgoing emails.
Marcus also emphasizes the importance of reliable email delivery. He emphasizes that “Mailbox.org” offers 99.9% delivery reliability and is very proud of its service. He also points out that his provider “Mailbox.org” has one of the highest levels of data protection.
In summary, both providers emphasize the importance of reliable email delivery, which is of great importance for all companies.

Our conclusion: Fasthosts vs. Mailbox.org – which email provider is better?
In this post, I have compared Fasthosts and Mailbox.org, two email providers with a long history. Both providers are very well established and offer a wide range of features, as well as very good service.
But in my opinion, Mailbox.org has the upper hand when it comes to data protection and security. This is because all of its servers are located in Switzerland, which means that your data is protected from unwanted access by third parties.
However, this does not mean that Fasthosts is worse in terms of data protection.
Fasthosts has a strong focus on GDPR compliance and offers many features for companies, which are not available on Mailbox.org. This is why Fasthosts is the best choice for larger companies, which have to deal with huge amounts of incoming and outgoing emails every day.
However, companies with less email traffic and/or a limited budget can also benefit from the services of Mailbox.org. Both providers offer very good email security and have an easy-to-use email interface.

Email is the most ubiquitous and popular communication channel in the world. More than 5 billion users check their inbox every day. The problem is that email systems are built around a simple protocol: sending and receiving. The rest is left to the email service providers and email marketers.
In the last few years, the rise of ESPs has led to a more advanced industry that offers more sophisticated features to help brands and users get the best from their email. It has also brought us a host of new challenges, including the lack of standards and security issues.
Most ESPs offer great value for money, but some shine above the rest. Below is a roundup of my favorite email service providers in 2016, based on features, pricing, and customer support.
Here is my list of the best email service providers for your business:
HubSpot’s marketing email service comes with a free plan that has a daily limit of 2,000 emails and a monthly limit of 10,000 emails, as well as some limited features. The free plan allows you to create unlimited email templates, automate email sequences, track your email campaigns, and more. You can also start a free trial for a paid plan with more features, such as advanced tracking, split testing, customized landing pages, and more.
HubSpot’s marketing tools have been optimized for the modern marketer. As part of their free plan, users get access to HubSpot’s Marketing Grader, which lets them find out how their content is performing and identify areas of improvement.
HubSpot’s customer support is top-notch. You can easily get in touch with them through their help desk or email, and they respond quickly and efficiently.
Mandrill is an email service provider that offers both a free and paid version. With Mandrill, you can send up to 250 emails per day for free, and you can send unlimited emails for $20 per month. If you go with the free plan, you get a host of features like tracking, A/B testing, spam testing, and list management.
MailChimp’s service is free for the first 2,000 subscribers. After that, you can subscribe for $19.99/month.
The free version comes with some amazing features that make it a great email service provider. For example, you can create, send, and track your emails from anywhere. You can also schedule emails, use A/B testing, and more.
The best thing about MailChimp is that they have a great customer support system. If you ever run into problems, you can contact their support team through email or phone.
GetResponse’s pricing starts at $15/month for a basic plan. They offer three plans that differ in features and number of emails per month:
Essential Plan – Up to 500 subscribers, 10,000 emails/month, $15/month
Plus Plan – Up to 1,000 subscribers, 25,000 emails/month, $49/month
Pro Plan – Up to 5,000 subscribers, 100,000 emails/month, $125/month
Campaign Monitor is an email marketing platform that offers two plans. The basic plan costs $9/month for up to 2,500 subscribers. The professional plan costs $25/month for up to 12,500 subscribers. Both plans come with a 30-day free trial.
If you need to send more than 12,500 emails per month, you can subscribe to the enterprise plan, which starts at $30/month.
Campaign Monitor is one of the oldest email marketing platforms, so you can trust that their software is reliable and well-designed.
The customer support team is also very helpful.
SendGrid’s service starts at $15/month for up to 40,000 emails per month, and it goes up to $75/month for 100,000 emails per month. If you need to send more emails, you can contact their customer support team and request a custom plan.
SendGrid offers a 14-day free trial, which gives you access to the same features that paid customers have. You can use the free trial to test the platform and see if it’s right for your business.
SendGrid is one of the best email service providers on the market, and they offer a wide range of features that will make your life easier.
AWeber’s service starts at $19/month for up to 500 subscribers. It goes up to $149/month for 2,500 subscribers. If you need to send more emails, you can contact their customer support team and request a custom plan.
AWeber’s customer support is one of the best in the industry. Their staff is very knowledgeable and will be able to help you with any problem that you might have.
Getting started with AWeber is very easy, and their support team is very helpful.
Crisp is a new email service provider that offers a free plan for up to 2,000 emails per month. If you need more email sends, you can contact their customer support team and request a custom plan.
Crisp is one of the best email service providers on the market, and they offer a wide range of features that will make your life easier.

The problem with these kinds of surveys is that they are self-selecting. The people responding are not necessarily representative of the general email market. I would say that Gmail has the best infrastructure (they're really aggressive about email security), but there are probably better providers out there. For example, my friend Steve Crescenzo recommends FastMail.
What makes a great email provider?
It has to be secure. It has to be usable. It has to be flexible.
It has to work. If it's slow, buggy, or doesn't work reliably, then it's a non-starter. It has to be able to be customized to your needs. If you don't want to use it, or it doesn't offer the things you want, you won't use it. I'd say that email clients on smartphones and tablets are the best of the bunch right now. I prefer the "lightweight" apps like Gmail, but if you want a full desktop client with lots of features, I'd recommend Mozilla Thunderbird.
What are your thoughts about the trend toward integrating email and instant messaging features (like Facebook's Chat, Gmail's Hangouts, and Yahoo! Mail's Messenger)?
I think it's a great trend, but the reality is that it's too new to really say for sure whether it's going to stick. For me, it's more of an annoyance, as I tend to be more interested in what people write, not what they say.
The more interesting question to me is whether companies can make this trend last. There's still lots of competition for email, and I think it's very difficult to compete with existing players like Gmail and Yahoo!.
Do you think email's golden age is in the past?
I think the golden age is the one we're in right now. For me, it's not the platform that matters so much as the person at the other end.
What are the biggest email problems today and in the future?
The biggest problem is email volume. The volume of emails we get is growing at a much faster rate than we can grow our own inboxes.
I think the biggest problem is that email was never intended to be a central point for communicating. It was never designed as a single place to put all your conversations, and that's really what we want.
What's one thing you wish you could tell businesses and individuals about email?
I'd say don't spend so much time on email. It's really not that important. Email is not the only way to communicate with others, and even when it is, it's not the most effective way. The best way to communicate with someone is to talk to them in person, not over email.</s>

Before you start your search for the right email provider, you need to know exactly what you want to achieve with your email marketing strategy.

Features - Some email providers offer a range of features that may be useful for your needs. For example, some providers offer integrated calendars, task management, and collaboration tools.
Cost - The cost of an email provider can vary widely. Some providers offer free plans, while others may have a subscription fee.
Reputation - It's also a good idea to research the reputation of an email provider before choosing it. Look for reviews and ratings from other users, and consider the provider's reputation in terms of reliability, security, and customer service.
Ultimately, the choice of an email provider is a personal one that depends on your specific needs and preferences. It's a good idea to compare different providers and choose one that offers the features and services that are most important to you.
Gmail and Hotmail are both widely used email providers, and both have their pros and cons. Here are some of the key differences between them:
Gmail has a much larger user base than Hotmail, with more than a billion active users worldwide. This makes it a popular choice for businesses and individuals alike, as it's easy to find other users to collaborate with or communicate with.
Hotmail, on the other hand, has a smaller user base, but it's still a popular choice for many people. It offers many of the same features as Gmail, such as a convenient interface, integration with other services like Skype, and a free email account.
Gmail has a reputation for being more reliable than Hotmail, as it has a larger team of engineers and a more advanced infrastructure. This means that it's less likely to experience outages or other technical problems.
Hotmail has improved significantly in recent years, and it's now known for being a reliable email provider. However, Gmail's reputation for reliability makes it a more attractive option for many users.
Gmail offers a wider range of features than Hotmail, including features like Google Drive integration, Google Hangouts, and Google Calendar integration. These features can be useful for collaboration and communication.
Hotmail also offers some useful features, such as the ability to integrate with Skype, create email rules, and customize the interface. However, Gmail's wider range of features makes it a more versatile and useful option for many users.
In terms of email security, Gmail has a strong reputation for protecting users' information. It offers features like two-factor authentication, encryption, and malware protection, which can help to keep users' data safe.
Hotmail also offers some security features, such as the ability to block spam and phishing emails, but it's not known for having as strong security measures as Gmail.
Gmail's interface is known for being user-friendly and easy to use, with features like conversation threads and smart labels that can help users organize their inbox.
Hotmail's interface is also user-friendly, but it doesn't have as many features as Gmail's. However, it does offer features like the ability to personalize the interface with themes and customizable backgrounds.
It's worth noting that the interface of any email provider can be customized to suit your preferences, and you can also choose to use third-party apps and services to enhance your email experience.
Overall, Gmail and Hotmail are both reliable and popular email providers, but Gmail has a larger user base, a stronger reputation for reliability and security, and a wider range of features. If you're looking for a comprehensive and convenient email service, Gmail is a good choice, but Hotmail may be a better option if you're looking for a more personalized and customizable experience.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
Austin B. Cronin
Marketing Coordinator for Mailjet
Mailjet is a really great option. I personally like the visual interface, it’s super intuitive and easy to use.
In addition to email sending, it has really useful features to help you create and build out your email campaigns. You can add collaborative features through their Gmail plugin and their new Chrome extension, Collaboration Tool, which provides an easy-to-use way to review and provide feedback in the email composition process. Mailjet also offers a powerful API for custom integrations and the ability to integrate with most other tools.
It’s also pretty great on the privacy front, and has a strong uptime guarantee to help ensure emails get delivered.
What are some challenges that email marketers face?
I think the two main challenges email marketers face are deliverability and personalization. There are many email service providers (ESPs) available that offer good deliverability rates, but this is only the first step. To be truly effective, you need to be able to deliver personalized content to the recipients in a way that increases your open rate, click-through rate, and ultimately your sales.
What are some ways email marketers can overcome these challenges?
It’s best to start by looking at your ESPs in terms of the deliverability rates and personalization capabilities. It’s also a good idea to keep an eye on your open and click-through rates. This will give you an idea of what is and isn’t working and you can make adjustments accordingly.
When it comes to personalization, it’s important to keep the end goal in mind. For example, if you’re trying to increase sales, focus on how you can customize the content to resonate with the recipient. This could include using their name in the subject line or including specific information about the products they’re interested in.
Personalization can also involve using data from different sources, such as Google Analytics or other third-party sources. The key is to use this data to customize your content in a way that will be most relevant to the recipient.
As email marketers, what are some key ways we can stay ahead of the competition?
As an email marketer, it’s important to keep an eye on the competition and stay ahead of the curve. With the growing number of competitors in the email marketing space, it can be tough to stand out.
One way to do this is by focusing on your email deliverability rates. Make sure your emails are getting to the inbox and are not being marked as spam. You can do this by using a reputable ESP like Mailjet and working with them to ensure your emails are delivered properly.
Another way to stay ahead of the competition is to personalize your emails. By including the recipient’s name in the subject line or body of the email, you can help increase engagement and ultimately sales.
Finally, it’s important to stay ahead of the trends in the email marketing space. This includes understanding the latest developments in technology and staying up-to-date with the latest email marketing news and tips. By doing this, you’ll be able to use new techniques and tools to improve your campaigns and stay ahead of the competition.
If you could recommend one ESP to our readers, which one would it be and why?
In terms of ESPs, Mailjet is a great option for email marketers. It offers good deliverability rates and provides a variety of features to help you create and build out your campaigns.
It also has a strong API for custom integrations, so you can easily integrate it with other tools. In addition, it offers a collaborative tool for reviewing and providing feedback on email campaigns, as well as a Chrome extension for reviewing and providing feedback on email campaigns.
If you’re looking for an ESP that offers good deliverability rates and provides a variety of features to help you create and build out your email campaigns, I’d recommend checking out Mailjet.
Austin B. Cronin is a marketing coordinator at Mailjet, a cloud-based email platform that helps businesses create and send marketing emails and automate their email marketing campaigns. At Mailjet, Austin helps create content and provide educational resources on email marketing best practices and the latest industry trends.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
Matt Birchler: I have a lot of respect for Google, especially with their Gmail product. I also think Microsoft does a pretty good job with their service. As I said before, I have a lot of reservations about their data mining, but they’re great for basic email. Outlook.com is a nice experience, with some good features. I think both of those products are really good for most people.
I really dislike the experience with iCloud email and GMX, which has a very unfortunate user interface. I’d say that Mail.com is one of the best options out there, but they don’t offer a lot of the features that people need these days.
How important is the user interface for a successful email solution?
Matt Birchler: If you look at how Apple changed iOS and iCloud.com with iOS 8 and 9, they made it so people don’t have to use a third-party mail client for email anymore. It’s actually easier to manage multiple accounts now, even with Gmail, without a third-party app.
I think user interface is huge, because people are really looking for something that looks like their iPhone or iPad and is as simple as possible. As email changes, that’s something that users will really want.
How can webmail providers offer this type of experience to customers?
Matt Birchler: I think it’s really important to keep it simple and not try to change how people interact with email. It’s also important to have a reliable infrastructure, and one that offers good privacy settings. Webmail is becoming less popular, especially when you look at the numbers of business email accounts.
Are email clients still important for business users?
Matt Birchler: It’s a good question, and I think the answer is yes. We just talked about Mail.com, but I don’t think they’re doing a great job. We’re not really seeing them make changes to their user interface or their platform to be more accessible.
For example, Gmail doesn’t offer good attachment support. It makes you save your attachments to Google Drive, which I think is a big problem. If you’re working on a computer that doesn’t have enough space, you might have to find a way to save attachments to Google Drive or another cloud storage provider.
The experience with webmail is definitely becoming worse.
What do you think will change in the next few years with regards to the way people use email?
Matt Birchler: I think that people will want more personalization, more features, and better experiences in their email. I don’t think it’s going to become less popular. It’s still the best way to communicate with people.
I think that we’re going to see more personalization, more collaboration tools, and better ways of doing things.
Do you think that Gmail has done a good job with privacy?
Matt Birchler: I think that Google’s data mining is not great. They do a good job of offering users the option to delete their data, but the default is to save it, which I think is really unfortunate.
I think that Google is a little more proactive about removing data. That’s something that I’d like to see. I’d like to see them be a little more proactive about deleting data and giving people more control over what they share.
What is the future of email in the United States?
Matt Birchler: I think it’s going to become a little more complicated, and it’s going to be a little more complicated for people to find their email, and it’s going to be a little more complicated for people to manage multiple accounts. I think we’re going to see a lot of innovation around that.
If you look at what Microsoft did with Windows 10 and their Cortana platform, it’s pretty incredible how they can understand what you’re doing and what you’re talking about. I think there are going to be more tools that can analyze your behavior and help you find your email.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
I have used Mailbox.org and run my own email service based on Roundcube, Postfix, Dovecot, and MySQL. I also work with the team at Inky and use the Mailfence services from time to time.
Mailbox.org offers excellent email service at a very low price, while Inky offers free services and Mailfence has a unique user experience. I’d like to take this opportunity to tell the world about the service I run, which also comes with an open source code base.
I would like to see some additional security and privacy features for email communication. One of the main problems that we have is that people are often unfamiliar with the technologies that can help secure email. I hope that we will see more attention to security in the near future.
What do you think about services like Mailgun, Mailjet, and Sendgrid? How do these products compare to services like AWS SES and SendGrid?
Mailgun is a good tool for those who want to use their own email infrastructure. However, I think they lack a bit in terms of features and usability. Sendgrid is great for sending a very large number of emails in one go, but it doesn’t offer much else. AWS SES is pretty decent and has good documentation. However, it lacks support for encryption, which can make it difficult to use for sending sensitive information.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
We get asked that question quite often and our answer is always the same: Zoho Mail. It’s not surprising as Zoho Mail is our flagship service for email and we are very proud of what we’ve built in it. It is an open-source, secure, and privacy-centric email service.
So, if you’re looking for a better email service, we recommend trying Zoho Mail. There’s a free plan available so you can try it out before you commit to any of our paid plans.</s>

With the growing complexity of cybersecurity challenges and the ever-increasing number of security breaches, it’s clear that we can’t leave our email security to chance.
To be successful, we must be proactive and implement a strategy that includes a multi-layered approach to security and a commitment to training employees on the importance of cybersecurity and how to stay safe online.
In this guide, we will discuss the most effective strategies to secure your email and keep your data safe.
We will explore the importance of securing your email, the best practices for email security, and how to keep your data safe and secure.
We will also provide some best practices for securing your email and advice for protecting your data from cybercriminals.
Email is one of the most commonly used platforms for communication and collaboration, making it a prime target for cybercriminals.
However, many people don’t realize that their email is often the first line of defense against cyberattacks.
To help you protect yourself and your organization, we’ve compiled a list of the most effective strategies for securing your email and keeping your data safe.
What Makes Email the First Target of Cybercriminals?
First, cybercriminals want to get their hands on your data.
Emails contain a wealth of information about the recipient, including their name, address, phone number, and financial details.
They are also an easy target for phishing attacks, in which cybercriminals try to trick the recipient into revealing sensitive information.
By emailing a phishing link or downloading a malicious attachment, cybercriminals can access the recipient’s information.
As a result, it is important to be aware of the risks associated with email and to take steps to protect yourself and your organization from cyberattacks.
The First Step to Securing Your Email: Encryption
The first step in securing your email is to ensure that all communications are encrypted.
Email encryption is the process of converting plain text emails into an unreadable format.
This prevents cybercriminals from reading the contents of the email and stealing sensitive information.
In addition, email encryption ensures that only the intended recipient can read the message.
The Benefits of Email Encryption
There are many benefits of email encryption.
First, it ensures that sensitive information remains confidential.
By encrypting email, cybercriminals are prevented from reading the contents of the email and stealing sensitive information.
Second, email encryption ensures that only the intended recipient can read the message.
This helps to prevent email spoofing, in which cybercriminals send emails to unsuspecting recipients.
Finally, email encryption is a cost-effective way to protect your organization from cyberattacks.
Email encryption is a relatively simple process that can be easily implemented by your IT team.
It’s important to choose an encryption method that is compatible with your organization’s email system.
If you need help choosing an email encryption method, your IT team can provide guidance.
The Best Practices for Securing Your Email
Email security is a top priority for any organization.
To protect your data, your IT team should implement the following best practices:
– Encrypt all outgoing emails.
– Use a password manager to protect your passwords.
– Limit the number of people who have access to your email account.
– Train your employees on how to spot and avoid phishing scams.
– Use two-factor authentication (2FA) to protect your accounts.
– Use an anti-malware program to scan for and remove viruses.
– Back up your data regularly.
– Make sure your systems are patched and updated.
– Monitor your email accounts for suspicious activity.
By following these best practices, you can help protect your organization from cyberattacks.
The Best Way to Protect Your Email: Train Your Employees
Training your employees on email security is the best way to protect your data.
Employees are the first line of defense against cyberattacks, and it’s important to educate them on how to identify and avoid phishing scams.
In addition, employees should be trained on how to spot and report suspicious activity.
Finally, employees should be trained on how to use encryption and two-factor authentication (2FA) to protect their accounts.
By training your employees, you can help keep your data safe and secure.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
My first choice for email providers is Gmail (as a cloud service). It has an excellent user interface, as well as a wealth of features and settings for sorting your emails into folders and managing your own personal address. You can even set up a POP or IMAP account in Gmail, which gives you a local copy of your email and allows you to send emails from your email client without going through Gmail’s servers (which might be helpful if you’re using Gmail on multiple computers).
For a personal address that doesn’t involve paying for a webmail service, I recommend using a service like Zoho Mail. Zoho Mail has some great features, like custom domain names, free SSL encryption (which protects against eavesdroppers) and email filtering, as well as an excellent user interface and a good variety of plugins (extensions).
What other email services do you find valuable?
My second choice for email providers is Gmail, as a desktop application. It’s not a true cloud service like Google Apps or Dropbox, but it’s pretty good for a non-cloud service. It has all of the features I expect from a personal email service: I can view my emails on multiple devices and send emails from my desktop, but I can also manage my account from the web interface (which I can use if my computer crashes).
My third choice for email providers is Zoho Mail. Zoho Mail is the best alternative to Gmail that I’ve used, though it has a slightly different feature set and design (which may be good or bad depending on your preferences).
What email provider do you use?
My personal favorite email provider is Zoho Mail, but I also use Gmail (as a cloud service). Zoho Mail is the best email service I’ve used, but Gmail is still the best service overall.
You can read more about Gmail on my blog.</s>

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
The short answer is: not one.
You see, there is no one email service provider that stands out in every single feature.
Some providers like Fastmail are known for excellent inbox management, while GMX is known for its excellent spam filters.
But there is one email provider that has proven itself to be very reliable, which is Outlook.com.
If you want to have an inbox that you can always count on, that never goes down, then you have to go with Outlook.com.
The reason that we give Outlook.com so much credit is that they have proven time and time again that they will not go down for any reason.
On the contrary, we have seen providers like Gmail going down several times a year. Even Fastmail, which is considered to be one of the more reliable email services, has gone down several times in 2021.
But Outlook.com has never gone down.
In fact, their email service has been down for less than 10 minutes in the last 10 years. That is absolutely unheard of in the email world.
Not only do they have a stable and reliable email infrastructure, but they also have a feature set that is unparalleled.
They provide a feature that is not offered by any other email provider: Sweep, which is a feature that will allow you to automate the removal of any email that is not relevant to you.
This is a very useful feature that is offered by few email providers, and Outlook.com has it.
If you have a busy inbox, then you should definitely give Outlook.com a try.
We hope that this article was helpful and that it gave you a good idea of which email service provider to choose for your email needs.</s>

While our clients know exactly which email provider they use, we cannot tell if it's the client's provider, or our own service.
Inbox organization depends on a few things.
First, it depends on your own inbox organization.
Second, it depends on the recipient's inbox organization.
Third, it depends on the way the email service provider (ESP) delivers emails.
For the ESP, this is the point of contact. The email goes to the ESP, and it is then forwarded to the client's (your) server. And it's there that delivery is attempted.
This is where we start seeing problems.
In the past, we've had problems with Constant Contact, Mail Chimp, Aweber, and many others that either wouldn't deliver email at all, or would deliver it too slowly. The result was spam-like.
So we tested. We tested many different providers. We discovered that the best providers for delivery consistency are Google and Amazon.
And for collaborative tools, they're better than the rest, too.
With the Google suite, not only can you send and receive email, but you can also send and receive SMS, and create docs, spreadsheets, presentations, and videos. All with just your email address.
With Amazon, you can send and receive email from within their AWS environment. They have excellent deliverability, too.
We chose to go with Google and AWS, not because it was the easiest to set up, but because the results were most reliable.
Our only concern is that Google and Amazon have been known to change terms of service, which can cause a lot of confusion.
The best advice is to use a service with the best reputation for reliability and consistent deliverability. And if it has any flaws, we should all just keep sending them emails.</s>

When it comes to choosing the best email service provider for email marketing, there are a few key factors to consider.
– Email delivery rate: This is the percentage of emails that are successfully delivered to the intended recipient.
– Inbox placement rate: This is the percentage of emails that are placed in the recipient’s inbox rather than their spam folder.
– Spam complaint rate: This is the percentage of emails that are flagged as spam by the recipient.
– Bounce rate: This is the percentage of emails that are returned to the sender as undeliverable.
– Unsubscribe rate: This is the percentage of subscribers who choose to unsubscribe from the mailing list.
– Engagement rate: This is the percentage of recipients who open and click on emails in a mailing list.

<s> In your view, which email provider stands out for its outstanding results, not just in terms of inbox organization but also in features like collaborative tools, privacy settings, and a reliable infrastructure for email delivery?
Oliver Frese: The biggest email providers are still dominated by Microsoft (Outlook, Office365, Azure) and Google (Gmail, Google Apps, Google Cloud). These companies are the main competition for us.
Given the different types of customers who use our product, we don’t think that there’s a clear winner, even though they have many advantages. Their biggest downfall is the fact that they’re not email-focused. They focus on other services like CRM and collaborative tools. In addition to email, email-specific providers like MailChimp, GMass, and others also offer collaborative tools. For me, it’s not easy to decide on a clear winner in this area.
Today, many companies are moving away from Microsoft to GSuite. I don’t see them as competitors, since we focus on a different target group. I have the same opinion for MailChimp. Although they’re a competitor on the business-to-business side, MailChimp focuses on a different target group. On the end-customer side, we can also consider Zapier, Active Campaign, and other platforms as competition for us.
Which email platforms and service providers do you feel are not well-suited for enterprise email?
Frese: Most providers can meet the needs of an enterprise. But some offer less features, are not as reliable, or don’t provide good support.
It depends on what the customer wants. As a company, you can’t just look at the number of features. I would definitely not recommend Google for email delivery due to the high spam rates. They offer a reliable, fast, and simple infrastructure, but when it comes to email delivery, they’re not the best option.
We recommend Zoho as a reliable and fast email service provider, but they don’t offer an extensive set of features.
The best enterprise providers for email delivery and the best enterprise providers for email-focused features aren’t always the same ones.
Which email-specific providers do you recommend for organizations that want to deliver personalized emails and make sure that their emails go straight into the inbox?
Frese: The biggest and most important providers here are MailChimp, SendGrid, and Twilio SendGrid. But I’d also recommend SendinBlue, Elastic Email, and Zoho.
In the last 12 months, there has been a big change in email marketing. More and more companies are starting to integrate email with other marketing channels, so it’s more important than ever to deliver personalized emails. It’s also important to make sure your emails go straight to the inbox. Email-specific providers like MailChimp, SendGrid, and Twilio SendGrid offer great support, especially for delivery. You get a dedicated IP address, which guarantees a higher acceptance rate and also helps to solve problems in the future.
If you want to personalize your emails and make sure they go to the inbox, you should use an email-focused provider for deliverability. If you want a platform that offers more features for personalization, you should look at email providers like Hubspot, Mailjet, and AWeber.
Are there any email-specific providers you’d recommend for companies that don’t have an email team or are looking for a software solution with minimal maintenance effort?
Frese: The best-known providers are Mailchimp, Constant Contact, Mailjet, and the like.
I think these providers are fine for small companies and startups that want to get their email marketing going as fast as possible.
For large companies, I’d recommend looking for an in-house solution.
Many of the email-specific platforms on the market have a very strong focus on deliverability and don’t provide an email platform as an application. Most of these applications don’t meet the requirements for IT departments.
What are some reasons why your company would recommend using an email service provider like CM Group over a free solution?
Frese: You can’t compare CM Group with MailChimp, GMass, or Zapier. CM Group is a cloud-based software-as-a-service, which focuses on business email, so we’re not an email platform as an application. In a nutshell, we offer a SaaS solution that’s easy to integrate into a CRM system like Salesforce or Hubspot.
One of our biggest competitors is Zapier. With Zapier, you can create integrations with many applications. But the problem is that there are many APIs and that the integration isn’t always the best option. With CM Group, you always have a very high-quality integration. This is an advantage over many other solutions.
What features does CM Group offer that GMass, for example, doesn’t?
Frese: CM Group offers an email delivery platform that supports email marketing and sales. CM Group is not just a “one-trick pony” like GMass. Our solution is ideal for companies that send a lot of emails, like sales reps who have many clients, or digital marketers who want to personalize their emails.
With CM Group, you can automate repetitive emails and easily integrate your email campaigns into other systems like CRM, ERP, and customer support. This can be done via webhooks or REST APIs.
For me, GMass is not a real competitor to CM Group. It’s an extension for GMail. You can’t compare these two. You can use GMass to send mass emails via Gmail and create a list to be used for sales. This is very basic, and I don’t think it’s a real alternative for us.
What are some of the biggest differences between an email-specific service provider and a more general, all-in-one CRM tool like Salesforce?
Frese: Email is a part of the CRM, not just a function. You can use your email solution to send marketing emails to all customers, but you can also use it for internal emails, to manage tasks, and more.
I’d compare an email-focused solution with MailChimp, SendGrid, or Zapier. They’re very focused on email. With an email-specific solution like GMass, you can only send mass emails, and you can only use it for marketing emails.
When it comes to sales, you need more features than just sending email. CRMs offer more features, like sales automation, lead management, and more. In my opinion, an email-specific solution and a CRM shouldn’t be compared.
How can enterprises choose a CRM tool that meets their email and sales needs?
Frese: Every company has different needs. For sales teams, CRMs offer a lot of functionality that’s very helpful for managing your sales team. But not every sales team needs it. So the first step is to decide if you need a CRM for your sales team.
If you’re not sure, try out the free version. It’s possible to integrate the email solution into your CRM. If you can do this, it’s a good decision to buy the CRM tool.
In my opinion, you shouldn’t compare email-specific solutions with CRM tools like Hubspot or Salesforce. They offer different functionality.
What are some of the biggest challenges you see companies and email teams facing when it comes to deliverability and productivity in 2019?
Frese: Email-specific platforms are not an issue. As we said earlier, you can easily integrate your email into your CRM, so it’s not a problem.
But many companies are still struggling with email delivery, privacy, and their internal email structures. Most companies are organized into departments, and each department has their own email account, which makes it difficult to control email delivery and prevent mistakes.
We are working on a new product that offers more support for email delivery.

I think that a well-written email can lead to a high ROI. If your content is relevant to your audience, it will lead to conversions, and that will improve your email ROI.
What do you think is the most difficult problem to solve with email marketing?

How did you first get into email marketing? What are some of the most important lessons you’ve learned over the years?
I first got into email marketing when I started working as a web developer for an email marketing company in the mid-1990s. I started building email lists for clients, and the more lists I built, the better my skills became at analyzing data and segmenting lists based on customer behavior and preferences.
I started learning about email marketing by attending conferences and reading articles written by industry experts. I have learned many things over the years, but the most important lessons I have learned are:
– It’s not about volume; it’s about quality
– Email list building requires patience and persistence
– The best email marketing campaigns are those that are tailored to the needs of each recipient
What is your greatest accomplishment as an email marketer?
As a web developer, I was involved in building email lists for a large number of clients. I learned how to analyze data and segment lists based on customer behavior and preferences. As a result of this experience, I have been able to use this knowledge to create successful email campaigns for myself and my clients.
How do you stay up to date on email marketing news and trends? What are some good sources to check out?
I stay up to date on email marketing news by reading email newsletters from industry experts. There are many email newsletters that I subscribe to, including EMarketer, MarketingSherpa, and Email Marketing Reports.
In your view, what is the future of email marketing?
I think that email marketing is changing in the same way that traditional marketing is changing. Companies are now using email as a way to engage with their customers, rather than simply sending them emails to try and sell them products. This means that companies need to focus on delivering value to their customers, rather than simply trying to sell them products.

How are you involved with your industry’s trade group? What are some of the benefits of belonging to an association?
I am a member of the Direct Marketing Association (DMA). I believe that it is important to stay up to date on industry trends and best practices. Members of trade groups also have access to information that can help them make better business decisions.
What advice do you have for a marketer just starting out?
My advice for a marketer just starting out is to build your list and segment your list based on customer behavior and preferences. Once you have a list of customers, it is easier to analyze their data and send targeted campaigns.</s>
